editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO THE KINGS MOST ECCELLENT MAIESTIE: The Author wi≈øheth all Content and Happines.
div.p:
AMong≈øt all our Labours in this life (mo≈øt dread SOVERAIGNE) there are none better imployed then tho≈øe, which are ≈øpent in ≈øeeking after, and in e≈øtabli≈øhing in our ≈øelues, and others, true Content, and Happines:
For what doth it profit a man, if Math. 16. ‚Ä¢ 6. hee gaine the whole world, and ≈øu≈øtaine the damage of his ≈øoule? or what permutation ≈øhall a man giue for his ≈øoule? and deliuer it to be afflicted in this life with temporall di≈øcontent, and in the other with eternall torment: Will hee take to be an Emperor, or King of the whole Globe of the earth; to raigne with di≈øcontent, for ≈øeauen yeares, ouer all the people in the world? It is ≈øo hard an exchange, that none indued with rea≈øon would accept of ≈øuch conditions: for what is an Emperor, a King, or any man, but his Content, and Happines? To be, and not to be happy, is but to be by a priuation of well being, wretched, and mi≈øerable. Neither is it ≈øufficient to Happines, that a
man thinke him≈øelfe happy, and be not, for this is but an increa≈øe of mi≈øery; not to ≈øeeme to be, that which hee is, vntill it bee too late, to obtaine that which he would; true Content: whereby wee ≈øee, that true Happines is more woorth then Kingdomes; and true Content is more to bee e≈øteemed, then all the trea≈øures of the Ea≈øt, and We≈øt Indyes, ≈øince it indueth Emperors and Kinges with what≈øoeuer true goods they haue, and filleth Subiects with what they can de≈øire, if they will not de≈øire that which is hurtfull to them≈øelues: In≈øomuch, as let but a Prince e≈øtabli≈øh in him≈øelfe, his Court and Subiects, the practi≈øe of true Happines, they re≈øt and remaine, each
one reioicing at others good, and all well content, with that which euery one hath of his owne: and let him but permit, fal≈øe, and deceitfull Happines, to bee practi≈øed in him≈øelfe, and Subiectes; and doe what he can, hee and they will become wretched, and mi≈øerable, in all thinges el≈øe, ≈øauing in imaginations: which con≈øiderations haue moued mee to ≈øeeke out the pathes of Content, and ≈øet downe at large the way to true Happines, and Re≈øt, that I might thereby a≈ømuch as in mee lyeth, call all my Countrey men from the di≈øgu≈øtes, and di≈ø≈øentions of this age (which the iniquitie of here≈øie hath brought forth) to a rich Repo≈øe, and Ioy in our Lord.

And hauing Dedicated our Fir≈øt part, vnto the mo≈øt worthy Prince CHARLES your Sonne (whome God Almighty long pre≈øerue.) I could not ≈øet out the≈øe our Second labours, vnder the protection of any other, but your Maie≈øtie: For ≈øeeing I am to ≈øpeake of Content, and Happines, to whome may I more fitly dedicate our labours, then to my Soueraigne, vnto whome aboue all men liuing I hartily wi≈øh them. Accept therefore mo≈øt dread Soueraigne, the protection of this our worke again≈øt all calumniators; and bee well plea≈øed, that true Content, and Happines, which your Maie≈øtie cannot but de≈øire to your ≈øelfe, may with your Gracious fauour, and vnder your protection, bee
communicated to all your Subiects: that all di≈ø≈øentions and di≈øcontentments taken out of your Highnes Kingdomes: it may bee verified of your Monarchy; which was ≈øpoken of Sion the Temple of God: The habitaiton in thee, is as it were of all Reioycing, P≈øal. 86. which is that I de≈øire, and hartily pray for, and ≈øo humbly ≈øubmit my ≈øelfe, and re≈øt,

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
DEare Reader, though ≈øo great bee the force of Happines to drawe all men to ≈øeeke after it; that there is not to bee found, any one ≈øo lo≈øt or forlorne, as publickely to profe≈ø≈øe, that he loueth afflictions and griefes; as they are vexations, and paines: yet ≈øuch is the pride and ob≈øtiancie of many, that rather then they wilbe conuinced to bee men of euill lines, they will defend that to be Happines, which they loue, and not that which is Happines indeed: and ≈øo heartily louing carnall libertie, and ≈øen≈øuall life, vnder fal≈øe pretexts, of Libertie of the
Go≈øpel, Iu≈øtification by Faith onely. A≈ø≈øurednes of ≈øaluation, &c. haue put Content and Happines in ≈øen≈øualitie of life, and not to be di≈øcouered, that they are Hogges (as Horace Hor. lib. 1 Epi≈øt. 4. ≈øaith) of the Heard of Epicures, doe craftily colour their Carnall libertie, vnder the vaile of Religion, and ≈øo per≈øwade as many as will beleeue them.

Whereupon it followeth that according to their Doctrine, they cannot be happy without the libertie of committing Fornication, adultery, theft, and preaching what≈øoeuer ≈øugge≈øtions of the deuill, or thoughts ≈øhall ari≈øe in their mindes &c. Since as they ≈øay, they haue not Freewill, or power to re≈øi≈øt them, or doe otherwi≈øe, and hee was neuer e≈øteemed happy, who was bound to ob≈øerue, that which was aboue his power and might.

div.p:
And accordingly to this,
they teach, and preach for Religion, that all the actions of men are of their owne Nature mortall ≈øinnes, worthy of euerla≈øting paines, as well the be≈øt as the wor≈øt: that all ≈øinnes are equall: that euill thoughts not con≈øented vnto are mortall ≈øinnes, and that as grieuous mortall ≈øinnes, as if they had committed the fact: Whereupon they inferre that it is not po≈ø≈øible to keepe the Commaundements of God, or merite any thing by well doing, and ≈øo craftily colouring their Epicuri≈øme vnder the pretext of Religion, they ≈øeeme to their followers, neither to deceiue, nor bee deceiued in their opinions, or practi≈øe of Happines; but by this craft pre≈øerue their credits, and liue without ≈øu≈øpition of wretchednes; and yet take to them≈øelues libertie to doe, what
their Fle≈øh or concupicences doe de≈øire, without re≈øpect either to God or man, more then the warine≈ø≈øe, not to incurre the forfeitures, and pennalties of Penall Lawes: In≈øomuch as that they haue put Con≈øcience (which in Catholicke times, men v≈øed to carry in their hearts, and ≈øoules) into their neighbours eyes; that if he ≈øee them not doing ami≈ø≈øe, to accu≈øe them to a Iudge, & bring them within the compa≈ø≈øe of ≈øome penall Lawe, all is well; Cal lib. 3 in≈øt ca. 14. MelaÃÑct. in locis anni 1521. tit. de peccato: and their followers. Cicero de leg. In the ≈øight of God, their be≈øt, and wor≈øt workes, are of their owne nature (as they ≈øay) all equally mortall ≈øinnes; And he who feareth nothing but a Iudge, and a witnes (as Cicero a Heathen man well ob≈øerued) What will not he doe in the darke?

And this policy, the≈øe Libertines
haue borrowed from Epicurus, a heathen Philo≈øopher, who hartily louing carnall libertie, and ≈øen≈øuall life; not to be of all men contemned, and accounted as a bea≈øt, would not in plaine tearms defend publickely: That man had no other happines then ≈øen≈øuall life, but coloured his La≈øciniou≈øne≈ø≈øe vnder pretext of Religion, and taught for truths: That the Soule of man was mortall: and that after death there was no reward for good deedes, and ≈øo by denying of merite for good workes, and puni≈øhment condigne to wicked deedes (with the Lutherans and Calueni≈øtes Engli≈øh Creed Art. 11. of this age) he founded his Sect, Happines, and Religion, vpon the groundes of Faith onely, without merite for good workes, or exerci≈øes of vertue: and by this craft, did what his
concupi≈øcences de≈øired, and yet pre≈øerued his credit, of being a Philo≈øopher; and found many followers in all ages: In≈øomuch as St. Augu≈øtine (before his Conuer≈øion to our Catholicke Church) if he could haue beleeued the Epicurian Articles, had made him≈øelfe of the Sect of the Epicures, as hee ≈øaith in the≈øe wordes: Nothing did call me, from the deepe gulfe of carnall Augu≈øt. lib. Conf. 8. cap. 16 plea≈øures, but the feare of death, and the Iudgement of God to come, which (notwith≈øtanding the diuers opinions I held) neuer departed from my bre≈øt: And I did di≈øpute with my friends, Alipius, and Nebridius of the ends of good, and euill: and Epicurus had caried away the prize in my minde, had I not beleeued that after death, there did remaine
a life of the Soule, and places proportionable to our merits, which Epicurus would not beleeue. So S. Augu≈øtine.

And from this Epicurian Doctrine of Prote≈øtants, and libertie of their Go≈øpell, proceedeth their aboundant fruites, and workes of the Fle≈øh; which are ≈øo copious, that as their owne Authors doe te≈øtifie; In Flaunders Richard Iefferie in his Serm. printed 1605. page 31. was neuer more drunkenne≈ø≈øe, In Italie more wantonne≈ø≈øe, &c. In Iurie more hypocri≈øie, In Turkie more impietie, In Tartarie more iniquitie, then is practi≈øed generally in England. The people (of Stubbes in his Epi≈øtle dedicatory before his Booke of good Workes. England ≈øaith another of their Authors are) in mo≈øt places di≈ø≈øolute, proude, enuious, malitious, di≈ødainfull, couetous, ambitious, carele≈ø≈øe of good workes. So the≈øe two
Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Authors; yet the one affirmeth Iefferie that hee ≈øpoke what he had plainely ≈øeene in the cour≈øe of ≈øome trauels, and the Stubbes other what hee had found in trauelling the whole Realme round about. And according to the te≈øtimonies of the≈øe two, is the Lamentation of the Puritans, in their milde defence, alleaged in Mr. Powels Booke, of thinges indifferent, ≈øaying: What eye ≈øo blinde, that it doth not gu≈øhe out with teares, to behold the mi≈øery of our ≈øuppo≈øed glorious Church, I meane the great ignorance, the Superficiall wor≈øhip of God, the fearefull bla≈øphemies, and ≈øwearings in hou≈øes and ≈øtreets, &c. theft, lying, v≈øurie, &c. Againe: It is (≈øaith hee) a wonderfull thing, and full of In Serm. coni. Ger. Fer. 5. ≈øcandall, that from the time, in which the pure Doctrine of the Go≈øpell was fir≈øt called to light, the world ≈øhould dayly growe wor≈øe. div.head: OF EASE, REST, REPOSE, CONTENT, and Happine≈ø≈øe.
CHAP. I. That Man hath a complete Ioy and Content, proportionable to his being.
div.p:
ALmightie God hauing created all things of P≈ø. 113. 1 ‚Ä¢ . nothing, according to the di≈øpo≈øition of his will; as a pious Parent, and mercifull Creator, hath giuen to euerie thing a Content and Happine≈ø≈øe; which had, then it is ≈øo well ≈øatisfied, that it ≈øeemeth to de≈øire no more, but re≈øteth (and after his manner reioyceth)
as content, and well plea≈øed.

As wee ≈øee by experience, that he hath giuen to a Stone, a Content, to be in his Centure; Water, a Re≈øt, in the hollow places of the Earth; Ayre, a Repo≈øe, in his Region; and Fire, in his Sphere; Trees, Plants, and Hearbes, a Delight, in the fat and firmene≈ø≈øe of the Earth, tempered according to their properties; Birds, Bea≈øts, and Fi≈øhes, a Plea≈øure, in Meates, Places, Companie, and ≈øen≈øuall Delights.

And out of his infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, in creating euerie thing, hath al≈øo annexed vnto it ≈øuch a di≈øpo≈øition to order, and ≈øuch a propen≈øion to his good, and content; that take
but out of his place, a piece of Earth, (which of all the creatures of God Almightie is the meane≈øt) and giue it all things you can deui≈øe, and make the mo≈øt of it that po≈ø≈øible you can inuent, yet it will tend thither, and neuer be quiet, vntill it returne; in≈øomuch, as doe but take away that which holdeth it vp, pre≈øently it goeth thither of it ≈øelfe, and that infallibly.

And if by ≈øome accident, a ≈øubtile Vapour become to be inclo≈øed in ≈øome hollow place, or caue of the Earth, where it hath, as it were, a chamber prepared for to re≈øt in; it will be ≈øo vnquiet, that it wil teare in pieces Rockes and Mountaines, ouerthrow Ca≈øtles and Towers, and, as angrie, ≈øhake
the whole Earth, to a≈øcend vp to his place; and if it find but an i≈ø≈øue, or you make but a pa≈ø≈øage, it is gone.

Or if a gro≈ø≈øe vapour, by the heat of the Sunne, be drawne vp into the Region of the Ayre (as though it ≈øhould be exalted to higher dignitie) and there come, to be enuironed about with clouds, that it cannot de≈øcend, but mu≈øt ≈øtay there, it taketh his exalting in ≈øuch di≈ødaine, and ≈øtayeth with ≈øo great di≈øcontent, that by colli≈øion of bodies, and through earne≈øt pre≈ø≈øing, it throweth fire downe from Heauen, and cau≈øeth ≈øuch a thunder, as though it would teare the Heauens in pieces, and all to de≈øcend to his place of re≈øt,
there to remaine, where it was ordained, that it ≈øhould be, in his fir≈øt creation.

And the ≈øame we may ob≈øerue in Birds, Bea≈øts, and Plants: put them in a Soyle not accommodated to their properties, and they die; or take from Birds or Bea≈øts, their naturall Companie, Foodes, Places of abode, &c. and giue them what other thing el≈øe you can, yet out of angui≈øh and grief they wil pine away; and let them but loo≈øe, they are gone, to their ordained Companie, Meat, and Re≈øt.

Whereby wee may inferre, that ≈øince all creatures what≈øoeuer haue a Content and Re≈øt (which once had, then they ≈øeeme well plea≈øed, and de≈øire no more) that al≈øo Man hath
his Re≈øt & Happine≈ø≈øe, wherein al≈øo he may be ≈øatisfied and well plea≈øed.

And ≈øeeing God Almightie, as a mo≈øt prudent Creator, hath giuen to euerie thing a Content, proportionable to his being; it mu≈øt needes be, that Man, being a farre more excellent creature, then any of the Elements, Birds, Bea≈øts, Fi≈øhes, and Plants, mu≈øt haue a more excellent Content, then any of them; vnle≈ø≈øe we ≈øhould e≈øteeme God Almightie iniurious to the nature of Man; which cannot be, His Mercies (to Man) exceeding all P≈ø. 144. his Workes, being duely con≈øidered.

So hauing found out, that Man hath a Happine≈ø≈øe, and Content; it will be worthie of
our labour, to ≈øeeke, wherein it con≈øi≈øteth, and ≈øet downe the meanes, how to attaine vnto it; which wee will doe, by Gods grace, in the en≈øuing Chapters.

div.head: CHAP. II. That there is a God.
div.p:
THe foole hath ≈øaid in his P≈ø. 1 ‚Ä¢ . heart, there is no God. Fooles, who≈øe grieuous ≈øinnes and horrible crimes haue extingui≈øhed the right v≈øe of Rea≈øon, denie the fir≈øt Cau≈øe. Agent, Mouer, and Creator of all things; and de≈øcend to ≈øuch gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, as that they attribute that to Nothing, Chaunce, Fortune, or Accident, which proceedeth
from God: as though Nothing, or that which hath no being, were more potent then that which is; and could giue being, beginning, and motion to all things.

To di≈øpute again≈øt fooles, ob≈øtinate, and wilfull people, who haue lo≈øt wit and rea≈øon, is but to become fooli≈øh. To conuince them, there is no better argument, then to put them to the practice of their Doctrine; as when they are ≈øicke, hungrie, afflicted, or want any thing, to let them haue no other helpe, or ≈øuccour, then their Nothing, or Chance, to helpe them, vntill they change their Opinions; ≈øince, in their iudgements, Nothing is ≈øo potent, and actiue, as that it can giue being,
motion, and action to all things; it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie al≈øo, in their iudgements, be of ≈øufficient force, to helpe them in their nece≈ø≈øities, to re≈øt and content, without any other a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

Ari≈øtotle ≈øetting downe common places, and meanes how to find out arguments to conuince errors, and e≈øtabli≈øh truths, again≈øt Athei≈øts would not di≈øpute, but ≈øet downe this for an argument, ≈øaying, Such as doe doubt, whether Top. lib. 1. c. 9. they ≈øhould honor the Gods, or no, ≈øtand in need of paines. Such as are become ≈øo depriued of rea≈øon, as to thinke, that there was no God, nor honor due vnto God; to conuince them, were nece≈ø≈øarie paines, ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, and torments;
that the Truth, which Arguments, deriued from Rea≈øon, could not proue (again≈øt ≈øuch as had lo≈øt the right v≈øe of Rea≈øon;) yet Affliction and Paines might force them to confe≈ø≈øe. So the Deuils in Hell, though they cannot loue GOD Almightie, or ≈øerue, or adore him, as they ought, for that they are confirmed in Malice, and multitude of Sinnes; yet compelled by Affliction and Paines, Beleeue, that there Ia. 1. 19. is one God, and tremble: So forcible an argument is Paines and Afflictions again≈øt Athei≈øts, who denie God in their hearts; that it is of force ≈øufficient to conuince euen the Deuill, that there is a God.

So doe but leaue the≈øe Athei≈øts, who denie that there is a God, and e≈øteeme all things to happen by Chaunce and Fortune; in their Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and Afflictions, to Chaunce and Fortune; and permit nothing el≈øe to helpe them: then they vvill not onely beleeue, that there is a God, but al≈øo earne≈øtly per≈øwade others, that there is a God; and that hee is the rewarder of tho≈øe, vvho ≈øhew and v≈øe mercie to others; and puni≈øheth the cruell, and hard-hearted: According as it is vvritten in the Scriptures, ≈øaying, Ble≈ø≈øed Mat. 5. 8. are the mercifull, for they ≈øhall obtaine mercie. And in Mat. 7. ‚Ä¢ . what mea≈øure you meate, it ≈øhall be mea≈øured to you againe.
And God will render to euery Mat. 16. 27. man according to his workes: As it fell out of late yeeres in a certaine Engli≈øh Souldier, in the Garri≈øon at Flu≈øhing in Zealand; who whiles he was well in health, could not be per≈øwaded, that there was a God; but falling, by lewdne≈ø≈øe of life, into many di≈øea≈øes, wherewithall hee was grieuou≈øly afflicted and tormented, hee cryed out vnto him for helpe and mercie: Their infirmities were multiplied, P≈ø. 15. 3. after they made ha≈øt to ≈øeeke for remedies, and to call vpon God for helpe.
And this for proofe again≈øt Athei≈øts, that there is a God.

div.head: CHAP. III.That God is the content of Man, and that it is not po≈ø≈øible for Man to find any true Ioy, or Content, without enioying of God Almightie.
div.p:
MAn hauing lo≈øt by ≈øinne that which was giuen him by grace and fauour, the Content and Plea≈øure of Paradi≈øe, Gen. 1. 8. wherein, after his creation, he was placed, ≈øtill ≈øeeketh to recouer his auncient inheritance, Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Ioy, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe; old, and young; rich, and poore; Kings, and Pe≈øants; wi≈øe men, and fooles; all ≈øeeke after Ea≈øe, and Content: No man ≈øo forlorne, or decayed from
the fir≈øt originall of his Happine≈ø≈øe, that loueth and affecteth Affliction, Torments, and Paines, as they are Vexations and Griefes: but euerie one, how corrupt ≈øoeuer his nature is, through ≈øinne, yet he de≈øireth Repo≈øe, and Happine≈ø≈øe.

O Sonnes of Adam! ≈øeeke that you ≈øeeke; but there it is not, where you ≈øeeke it: you ≈øeeke for Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, in the Honour, Glory, Riches, Wealth, ≈øen≈øuall Plea≈øures, and Commodities of the World; where neuer yet was found, but their Oppo≈øites; Griefes, Angui≈øhes, Di≈øcontents, and Vnhappine≈ø≈øe: And whom ≈øhall we call for witne≈ø≈øe of this truth? the fooles
of the World? No; heare the Wi≈øe man ≈øpeake: I haue ≈øeene Eccl. 1. 14. all things that are vnder the Sunne; and behold, all are vanitie, and affliction of mind.

Is it po≈ø≈øible, that the ≈øonnes of the Earth cannot remember their Parents fall? That in the enioying, & familiar conuer≈øing with God in Paradi≈øe, the place of Plea≈øure, was all Ea≈øe, Content, and Ioyes; and bani≈øhed from thence, they were put, with all their po≈øteritie, into a cur≈øed Land, of Paines & Trauels: Cur≈øed is the Gen. 3. 17. Earth in thy work; with much toyling ≈øhalt thou eat thereof all the dayes of thy life; thornes & thi≈øtles ≈øhall it bring forth to thee. Great is the ignorance of Mankind, that looketh to gather Grapes of Thornes, and Figs of Thi≈øtles; Mat. 7. 16.
to ≈øeeke for Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, and Content, in the commodities of a cur≈øed creature; in the Mettalls, Herbage, skins of Bea≈øts, dead Fi≈øh & Fle≈øh, ≈øen≈øuall Plea≈øures, and corruption of the Earth: ba≈øe minds, to be deluded with ≈øuch ba≈øe contents, and gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, again≈øt which no rea≈øon or experience can preuaile.

God Almightie, in creating of Man, out of his infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, gaue him Vnder≈øtanding, Will and Memorie, according to his owne Image, as it is written; God created Gen. 1. 17. Man to his owne Image, to the Image of God he created him, male and female he created them; their ≈øoules, and formed their bodies of the ≈ølime of the
earth: God formed Man of the Gen. 2. 7. ≈ølime of the earth, and breathed into his face the breath of life, and Man became a liuing ≈øoule, bearing in his mind the Image and likene≈ø≈øe of God, Vnder≈øtanding, Will, and Memorie.
Vnder≈øtanding, to vnder≈øtand what was the chiefe≈øt good; God his Creator, of infinite Goodne≈ø≈øe, Beautie, Glorie, Maie≈øty, Excellencie, and Perfection.
And a Will, to will, loue, and ≈øeeke him at all times.

And a Memorie, to remember him in all his actions; with ≈øuch a capacitie of him, and hunger after him, that what≈øoeuer el≈øe hee ≈øeeketh, hee ≈øhould erre, and what≈øoeuer el≈øe hee ≈øhould finde, yet hee ≈øhould want; that, as it
were perforce, though otherwi≈øe hee would not, yet hee mu≈øt needes ≈øeeke after his glorious Maie≈øtie; ≈øince nothing el≈øe is able to content the ≈øoule of man, but God: as Cicero, a Pagan man, well ob≈øerueth; there were neuer any De Leg. lib. 1. people in the world ≈øo barbarous and irreligious, but that, although they knew not what God they ought to ≈øerue, and adore, yet they knew, that they ought to ≈øerue and adore ≈øome God. The light of rea≈øon, in the mo≈øt barbarous people, manife≈øting to them, that there could be no true Content and Happine≈ø≈øe, but in ≈øeruing and adoring God: though, for want of grace, they erred in the manner, and through ignorance, were deceiued, in their opinions, of
his diuine Maie≈øtie; yet all, with one con≈øent, cryed out, that God was to be ≈øerued, loued, and adored; ≈øeeing that there could be no true coÃÑtent, without the enioying of him.

God Almightie being onely He, that is Sum qui ≈øum, I am Exo. 3. 14. which am, and all other things being by participation froÃÑ his goodnes, depending vpon his Apo. 4. will; no creature can haue any true good content, or re≈øt, but in him, and from him: he being all Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, holdeth them in his hand, & coÃÑmunicateth them to his creatures at his plea≈øure; according to the ≈øaying of the Prophet: Thou ha≈øt made the P≈ø. 35. 11. wayes of life known to me, thou ≈øhalt make me full of ioy with thy countenance, delights are in thy right hand, euen to the end.
Againe, Thou opene≈øt thy hand, P≈ø. 103. 28. and fille≈øt euery liuing thing with thy ble≈ø≈øing.

All things created, being finite, and hauing limited perfections, cannot ≈øatiate the heart of Man; as wee ≈øee by experience, in the mo≈øt famous Mynions, and greate≈øt Potentates of the Earth; who though the world (ambitious to ≈øhew and ≈øet forth her pride and iolitie) hath rai≈øed to the highe≈øt fortunes and greate≈øt glorie ≈øhee had; yet could ≈øhe neuer be≈øtow vpon them one moment of true Content, or Re≈øt; but forced them to march, like galld-backt Mules, couered ouer with painted Saddles, and burdened with heauie burdens of Cares and Iealou≈øies
all the time of their liues; after death, to de≈øcend into eternall Mi≈øeries and Torments.

And to begin with Nynus, who liued in the third hundreth yeeres after the Floud, and was the Earths fir≈øt famous Mynion, exalted by her to that height of worldly honor and dignitie, that his Father Belus, and his Grandfather Nemrod, were ≈øtiled Gods, his Father called Iupiter, and his Grandfather Saturne, as Sator Deorum, the Father of the Gods; that for Nobilitie of Birth, Stiles, Titles, Di≈øcents, and Dignities, he was not inferiour to the highe≈øt that euer was vpon the Earth: and that his earthly power and might, might be
corre≈øpondent to his Styles Oro≈ø. li. 1. c. 1. et 4. and Titles, he was aduanced to the Monarchie of the A≈ø≈øyrians, Medes, and Per≈øians; ≈øo large Dominions, that vpon the fir≈øt view, hee alone ≈øeemed to enioy all the plea≈øures and be≈øt commodities of the Earth, from the South, vnto the Sea Euxinus, of foure Empires: Yet if wee ≈øeriou≈øly looke into the Content hee had in this his Greatne≈ø≈øe, you ≈øhall find nothing, but that the poore man was deceiued with bare Imaginations; liued fortie yeeres, the time of his reigne, vnder a heauie burthen of Cares, Iealou≈øies, Warres, and Dangers, to die a mi≈øerable death (wounded with an Arrow, ≈øhot from his enemies) without
any other benefit of all his worldly Greatne≈ø≈øe, Maie≈øtie, and Might, then encrea≈øe of eternall Torments.

The ≈øame we ≈øhall find in 4. Reg. 18. 19. Senacherib, the Earths ≈øecond Fauorite; whom ≈øhee ray≈øed to the Monarchie of the A≈ø≈øyrians, and made Conqueror of manie Kingdomes, and Vanqui≈øher of manie Kings, to adorne him with all their Trea≈øures and Plea≈øures: All which could not endue him with one moment of true Content, but loadened him for eighteene yeeres, the time of his reigne, with manie Troubles, and much Di≈øcontents; afterward, to be mi≈øerably murdered by two of his owne ≈øonnes, ≈øo to de≈øcend into eternall Torments.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. That Faith, or beleefe in God Almightie, is nece≈ø≈øarie to Mans Content and Happine≈ø≈øe: but not onely Faith, without the coniunction and connextion to other vertues.

div.head: CHAP. VI. That our Catholike Faith, which Protestants call Papistrie, is the Faith of God, planted by our Lord and Sauiour vpon Earth, is proued by the light of Rea≈øon in generall.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, by rea≈øon taken from the vnitie of our Catholike Faith; that people of all Nations, Tribes, and Countries, differing in Languages and Gouernment, di≈øper≈øed ouer the whole Earth, ≈øhould all beleeue as one, and one as all, and all with one voice, and in one ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øignification,

Againe, if you adde any thing vnto it, and ≈øay, that both the Bodie & Bloud of our Lord is there really, and al≈øo the Bread, then it is Lutherani≈øme; and ≈øo forth, of any other Article of our Catholike Faith. And if any oppo≈øe and ≈øay, that ≈øome e≈øteemed Catholikes haue or doe ob≈øtinately maintaine anie one point of Doctrine, contrarie to the Catholike Faith
(held and receiued ouer the World) and would not, nor will not, ≈øubmit his or their iudgements to the Catholike Church, and her Superiors; I an≈øwere, that hee or they were, and be, Schi≈ømatikes, or Heretikes, and haue, or are, to peri≈øh euerla≈øtingly: According to the Article of our Creede, which ≈øayth, Who≈øoeuer Athana. Creede. will be ≈øaued, it is needfull, before all things, that he hold the Catholike Faith; the which, vnle≈ø≈øe each one ≈øhall keepe whole, and inuiolate, hee ≈øhall, without doubt, eternally peri≈øh. In≈øomuch, as that it is impo≈ø≈øible for any one of our Catholike Church to di≈ø≈øent ob≈øtinately from our Catholike Church, ≈øince hee is bound by his Faith, to beleeue inuiolately,
and before all things, all the Articles of our Catholike Faith; and if hee ob≈øtinately faile herein, in any one point of Faith, hee is bound to beleeue, that hee ≈øhall, without doubt, eternally peri≈øh, according to our Creede.

So that the words which S. Ireneus (who liued ≈øo neere the Apo≈øtles times, that hee affirmed to haue ≈øeene S. Policarpe, who was S. Iohn the Euangelists Scholler) v≈øed again≈øt the diuers Sects of Heretikes in his time, wee may v≈øe now, without exchange. The Church, ≈øowne throughout the World, doth diligently keepeth is preaching, which it hath receiued, and this Faith, as wee haue ≈øaid, as it were
dwelling in one hou≈øe, and doth beleeue them, as if it were hauing one ≈øoule, and one heart, and con≈øonantly doth preach, teach, and deliuer the≈øe things, as if it had but one mouth. For although in the world there are different Languages, yet the vertue of Tradition is one and the ≈øame. So that neither the Churches which are founded in Germanie, doe beleeue otherwi≈øe; neither otherwi≈øe doe deliuer the≈øe which are in Spaine, neither tho≈øe which are in Aragon, neither tho≈øe which are in the Ea≈øt, neither tho≈øe which are in Egypt, nor tho≈øe which are in Libia, nor tho≈øe which are founded in the midde≈øt of the world. So Saint Ireneus, in his fir≈øt Booke, and ≈øecond Chapter, again≈øt Here≈øies; and we with him.

Prote≈øtants, though they haue but few affirmatiue Articles, which in the ≈øame words and ≈øen≈øe they defend as matters of Faith, and are but few in number, in re≈øpect of Catholikes; yet are they in them few Articles fir≈øt generally diuided into many Sects, as into Elizabethians, Lutherans, and Caluini≈øts; and many more le≈ø≈øer Sects, as Anabapti≈øts, Browni≈øts, De≈øperates, Pig-Recu≈øants, or Tra≈øquites, &c. The Elizabethians defend, that a woman may be Head of the Church, and hold the Supremacie, in all cau≈øes, and ouer all Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons who≈øoeuer, and put tho≈øe to death as Traitors, who refu≈øe to ≈øwear it as true; and giue Authoritie to Parliaments, to alter
formes of Religion: Lutherans and Caluini≈øts denie both. Caluini≈øts denie the Authoritie of Bi≈øhops, and Ordination of Mini≈øters by Bi≈øhops; Lutherans and Elizabethians defend both. The Lutherans defend Con≈øub≈øtantiation in their Supper, which they e≈øteeme a Sacrament; both Caluini≈øts and Elizabethians denie it. And ≈øecondly, be≈øides this Diui≈øion into generall Sects, they are all ≈øo particularly diuided, one from all, and all from euerie one, that there cannot be found anie two of them, which agree in vnitie of Faith; one to beleeue the ≈øame Faith, in the ≈øame words and ≈øen≈øe, that his companion doth beleeue, to Saluation:
All beleeuing, that the whole The Engli≈øh Creed, art. 19. et 2 ‚Ä¢ . Church and generall Councels may erre; yet euerie one beleeueth of him≈øelfe in particular, that he is a≈ø≈øured to be ≈øaued, and that he cannot erre. So that Faith which one Prote≈øtant beleeueth, to be ≈øaued by, all the re≈øt doubt, whether it be true, or no: And no other el≈øe will beleeue that which his companion beleeueth, for an Article of Faith; videlicet, That Titius is a≈ø≈øured to be ≈øaued, and cannot erre. Whereby they are diuided into as manie Sects, as Men. So that ≈øuppo≈øed, that vnitie of Faith, in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe and meaning, were nece≈ø≈øarie to Saluation, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, as it is;
and that any one Faith profe≈ø≈øed by any one Prote≈øtant man, could ≈øaue, and bring to Content and Happine≈ø≈øe; yet of all the Prote≈øtants that are, or euer were, or ≈øhall be, one only can be ≈øaued, and happie, ≈øince onely one agreeth with him≈øelfe in vnitie of faith, and with none of his companions Prote≈øtants who≈øoeuer.

Secondly, it is manife≈øt by rea≈øon, taken from the goodne≈ø≈øe of God Almightie, that our Catholike Faith is the Faith of God, planted by our Sauiour; for that God Almightie is of infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, and vertue, and ≈øo could not plant a Faith, or Religion, wherby men might be ≈øaued, and attaine to all goodne≈ø≈øe, content, and happine≈ø≈øe; but
it mu≈øt con≈øi≈øt of all vertues: becau≈øe hee cannot doe contrarie to his will; which is alwaies to will good, & vertue: which is our Catholike Faith, which teacheth, that it is not po≈ø≈øible for any man to be ≈øaued, or enter into Heauen, or enioy God, or haue anie true content, that hath anie vice, or iniquitie in his ≈øoule; as S. Paul ≈øayth, If any man 1. Tim. 6. 3. con≈øent not to that doctrine which is according to pietie, he is proud, knowing nothing: becau≈øe all men may and ought to know, that God Almightie is of infinite pietie, and ≈øo cannot plant a Faith, or Religion, which is not pious, and teaching all vertues, as nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øaluation, and vnion of heart with him, their happine≈ø≈øe.

Thirdly, that Faith and Religion, in all rea≈øon, mu≈øt be the Faith and Religion planted by God, which teacheth and ≈øheweth men the mo≈øt and be≈øt meanes how to loue God; this being an Argument in Nature and Grace, That euerie one loueth his owne. 3. Reg. 3. 26. Ioh. 5. 19. Whereby is manife≈øt, that our Catholike Religion is the true Faith; for that it teacheth vs, how to loue God with all our hearts, and how to obtaine Saluation, and Happine≈ø≈øe, by louing God: VVhereas Prote≈øtants doe teach Saluation, by onely Faith; and that it is impo≈ø≈øible to loue God, or keepe the Commaundements. And can there be a more vile and wicked Religion inuented,
then to teach, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to loue God Almightie with all our hearts?

Fourthly, by generall con≈øent of all People and Nations, though of different Religions; who all generally ≈øay and affirme, That Catholikes, liuing according to their Faith, and Religion, may be ≈øaued, and haue a ≈øparing (as ≈øome tearme it) ≈øauing Faith: And the con≈øent of all People, and Sects, and Nations, cannot erre in Rea≈øon.

div.head: CHAP. VII. That it is as certaine, that our Catholike Faith, which Prote≈øtants call Papi≈øtrie, is the Faith of God, planted by our Sauiour, as it is certaine that God Almightie cannot lye, or be for≈øworne; and how ea≈øily to end and determine all Controuer≈øies, by maintaining the Oath of God as true.
div.p:
BY my own ≈øelfe haue I ≈øworne, Gen. 22. 16. ≈øaith the Lord to Abraham; becau≈øe thou ha≈øt done this thing, and ha≈øt not ≈øpared thy onely begotten ≈øonne for my ≈øake, I will ble≈ø≈øe thee, and I will multiply thy Seed as the ≈øtarres of Heauen, and as the ≈øand that is by the Sea ≈øhoare; thy Seed ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe
the gates of his enemies, and in thy Seed ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt obeyed my voice.
Againe, our Lord promi≈øed to I≈øaack, ≈øaying, In thy Seed Gen. 26. 4. ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth, for becau≈øe Abraham obeyed my voice.

Againe, our Lord promi≈øed to Iacob, Thy Seed ≈øhall be as Gen. 28. the du≈øt of the Earth; thou ≈øhalt be dilated to the We≈øt, and to the Ea≈øt, and to the North, and to the South, and in thee and thy Seed all the Tribes of the Earth ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed.

Of the≈øe Promi≈øes, the Prophet E≈øay ≈øpeaketh, ≈øaying, I≈ørael ≈øhall flouri≈øh, and ≈øpring, I≈øa. 27. 5. and they ≈øhall fill the face of the world with Seed. Againe, I I≈øa. 61. 8. the Lord, that loue Iudgement,
and hate Robberie in Holocaust. And I will giue their worke in truth, and make a perpetuall Couenant with them. And they ≈øhall know their Seed in the Gentiles, and their Budde in the midde≈øt of Peoples: All that ≈øhall ≈øee them, ≈øhall know them, that tho≈øe are the Seed which the Lord hath ble≈ø≈øed.

And of this Oath, the ≈øame Prophet ≈øpeaking, ≈øayth, As in the dayes of Noe, is this thing I≈øa. 54 9. to me; to whom I ≈øware, that I will no more bring the Waters of Noe vpon the Earth: ≈øo haue I ≈øworne, not to be angrie with thee, and not to rebuke thee: for the Mountaines ≈øhall be moued, and the little Hills ≈øhall tremble (before the Day of Iudgement) but my Mercie ≈øhall not depart from thee, and

Of this Oath, the Prophet Daniel, in the Captiuitie of Babylon, maketh mention, ≈øaying, Take not away thy Dan. 3. 35. Mercie from vs, for Abraham thy beloued, and I≈øaack thy ≈øeruant, and I≈ørael thy holy one, to whom thou hast ≈øpoken, promi≈øing, that thou woulde≈øt multiplie their Seed as the ≈øtarres of Heauen, and as the Sand that is in the Sea ≈øhoare.

Of this Oath, the Prophet Dauid ≈øpeaking, ≈øayth, I will P≈ø. 88. 28 put him, the fir≈øt begotten, high aboue all the Kings of the Earth; I will keepe my Mercie vnto him for euer, and my Te≈øtament faithfull vnto him: I will put his Seed for euer and euer,

But if his children ≈øhall for≈øake my Law, and will not walke in my Iudgements; if they ≈øhall prophane my Mercies, and not keepe my Commaundements; I will vi≈øit their Iniquitie with a Rod, and their ≈øinnes with ≈øtripes: But my mercies I will not take away from him, neither will I hurt in my Truth: Neither will I prophane my Te≈øtament; violate his Oath. Againe ≈øpeaking of this Oath, and the≈øe Promi≈øes, hee ≈øayth, He hath beene P≈ø. 104. mindfull for euer of his Te≈øtament, of the Word which he commaunded vnto thou≈øand of Generations, which he di≈øpo≈øed to Abraham, and his Oath to I≈øaac, and he appointed it to Iacob for a Precept, and to I≈ørael for an eternall Te≈øtament.

That this Oath of God, and Promi≈øes to the Patriarkes, were to be fulfilled in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, and in Chri≈øtians, maintaining and profe≈ø≈øing the Faith of God, planted by our Lord and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the Scriptures abundantly do te≈øtifie. Our Lord expounding the Parable of the Cockle of the field, ≈øayth, He that Mat. 13. 37. ≈øoweth the good Seed, is the Sonne of Man, and the Field is the World, and the good Seed tho≈øe are the Children of the Kingdome, di≈øper≈øed ouer the World, according to the Oath of God to Abraham. Againe, our Lord ≈øayth, Doe Mat. 5. 18. not thinke, that I come to breake the Law, or the Prophets; I am not come to breake, but to fulfill. Againe, All things mu≈øt needes Luc. 24.
be fulfilled, which are written in the Law of Moy≈øes, and the Prophets, and the P≈øalmes of me.

Our Ble≈ø≈øed Ladie, ≈øpeaking of the fulfilling of this Oath in our Sauiour, and his Seede, the Chri≈øtians, ≈øaith, Hee hath receiued I≈ørael his Luc.
‚Ä¢ . 54. Child, being mindfull of his mercie, as he ≈øpake to our Fathers, to Abraham, and his Seede for euer. And Zacharie, repleni≈øhed with the Holy Ghost, prophecied, ≈øaying, Ble≈ø≈øed be Luc. 1. 68. our Lord God of I≈ørael, becau≈øe he hath vi≈øited and wrought the redemption of his people, as he ≈øpake by the mouth of his holy Prophets, that are from the beginning, to remember his holy Te≈øtament, the Oath which he ≈øware to Abraham our Father.

Of the fulfilling of this Oath, and the≈øe Promi≈øes, in our Sauiour, and Chri≈øtians, S. Peter ≈øpeaketh, ≈øaying, You are the Children of the Act. 31. 24. Prophets, and of the Te≈øtament, which God made to our Fathers, ≈øaying to Abraham, And in thy Seed ≈øhall all the Families of the Earth be ble≈ø≈øed.

That this Oath of God to Abraham, was to be fulfilled in Chri≈øtians, S. Paul euerie where witne≈ø≈øeth, ≈øaying, Of Act. 13. 25. his Seed, God‚ñ™ according to his Promi≈øe, hath brought forth to I≈ørael a Sauiour, Ie≈øus. Againe, Wee preach vnto Act. 13. 32. you the Promi≈øe, which was made to our Fathers, that God hath fulfilled the ≈øame to our Children. Againe, Paul Rom. 1. 1. the Seruant of Ie≈øus Christ,
called to be an Apo≈øtle, ≈øeparated in the Go≈øpel of God, which before he had promi≈øed by his Prophets, in the holy Scriptures of his Sonne, by whom we receiue grace and Apo≈øtle≈øhip, for obedience to the Faith, in all Nations. Againe, Abraham contrarie to Rom. 4. 18. hope, beleeued in hope, that he might be made the Father of many Nations, according to that which was ≈øaid to him, So ≈øhall thy Seed be, as the ≈øtarres of Heauen, and the ≈øand of the Sea. Againe, Know yee therefore, that they that are Gal. 3. 7. of Faith, the ≈øame are the children of Abraham. And the Scripture fore-≈øeeing, that God iu≈øtifieth the Gentiles by Faith, ≈øhewed vnto Abraham before, that in thee all Nations ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed. Againe, Christ hath Gal. 3. 17.
redeemed vs from the Cur≈øe of the Law, that on the Gentiles, the ble≈ø≈øing of Abraham might be made in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, that wee may receiue the Promi≈øe. Againe, to the Galathians conuerted to Chri≈øtianitie, he ≈øaith; Wee brethren according to I≈øaack, are the children of the Promi≈øe.

And ≈øpeaking of this Promi≈øe of God to Abraham more at large, ≈øaith; God promi≈øing Heb. 6. 13. to Abraham, becau≈øe he had none greater by whom hee might ≈øweare, hee ≈øware by him≈øelfe; ≈øaying: Vnle≈ø≈øe ble≈ø≈øing I ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe thee, and multiplying I ≈øhall multiply thee, &c. for men≈øweare by greater then them≈øelues, and the end of their controuer≈øie, for confirmation, is an oath: Wherein, God meaning more abundantly
to ≈øhew to the Heires of the Promi≈øe the ≈øtabilitie of his Coun≈øell, he interpo≈øed an Oath, that by two things vnmoueable, wherby it is impo≈ø≈øible for God to lye, we may haue a mo≈øt ≈øtrong comfort, who haue fled, to hold fa≈øt the Hope promi≈øed, which wee haue as an Anchor of the Soule, ≈øure and firme. So S. Paul.

Whereby thou ≈øee≈øt, deare Reader, that our Catholike Faith is as certaine the Faith of God Almightie, planted by our Sauiour, as it is certaine, that God Almightie cannot lye, or be for≈øworne: ≈øince there is not, nor euer was, any one Faith, or Religion, ≈øo dilated ouer the World, as our Catholike Faith is at this day; in the Ea≈øt, We≈øt, North, and South, in Europe, A≈øia, Africa,

Though Sects and Here≈øies haue ≈øomtime occupied many parts of the World; yet they either in ≈øhort time returned to the vnion of our Catholike Church, or el≈øe were conquered by barbarous Nations, and made their ≈ølaues, according to the Promi≈øes and Prophecies: As the Arrians in Lumbardie, and other places, by the Gothes; the Donati≈øts in Africa, by the Vandales; the Greekes, by the Sarazens, and Turkes. The Brittans (auncient Inhabitants of this I≈øland) admitting of the Pelagian Here≈øie,

Chapter.

Since Schi≈ømatikes and Heretikes will not honour God, by maintaining his Oathes and Promi≈øes to his Seed, and returne vnto the vnion of our Catholike Church, that they may be partakers of his Ble≈ø≈øings; God Almighty will be honoured, by manife≈øting the
fulfilling of his Maledictions and Cur≈øes vpon them: that the Iu≈øt may ≈øee, and feare and
P≈ø. 51. 8. confe≈ø≈øe, that God is true and iu≈øt in all his Wordes and Oathes. Reuenge is mine, ≈øaith
Deut. 32. our Lord, and I will repay them in time, that their foote may ≈ølide. They haue prouoked me, in that which was no God, and haue angred me in their vanities; and I will prouoke them, in that which is no People, and in a fooli≈øh Nation will I anger them. And as for Prote≈øtants; if euer there hath beene any Kings, Kingdomes, or Nations,
which haue made profe≈ø≈øion of that Faith Prote≈øtants doe now, before King Henrie the eight; we ≈øee by experience, that the Cur≈øes and Maledictions of God Almightie, ≈øpoken of by the Prophets, hath ≈øo fallen vpon them, that they were as people that de≈øcended into Hell quick; P≈ø. 54. 16. of vvhom there is no memorie in any Booke, Chronicle, Antiquitie, or Hi≈øtorie: Tho≈øe enemies of God, vpon whom the Prophet Moy≈øes ≈øpeaking, ≈øayth in the Per≈øon of GOD: I ≈øaid, Deut. 32. 26. Where are they? I will make their memorie to cea≈øe from among Men. In ≈øuch ≈øort, that there is le≈ø≈øe memorie of them, then of Sodome and Gomorra, vvhich vvas

Yet a little while, and the P≈ø. 36. 10. ≈øinner ≈øhall not be; and thou ≈øhalt ≈øeeke his place, and ≈øhalt not finde it. The enemies P≈ø. 36. 20. of our Lord, forthwith as they ≈øhall be honoured and exalted, vani≈øhing, ≈øhall vani≈øh as ≈ømoake. I haue ≈øeene the Impious highly exalted, and aduanced, as the Caedar of Libanus, And I pa≈ø≈øed by,

Which Prophecie wee ≈øee, of late yeares, to be fulfilled in Henrie the eight, King of England, and Henrie the ≈øecond, King of France. So, ≈øuppo≈øing thou beleeue≈øt, that God Almightie cannot

div.head: Acts of Faith.
div.p:
GOd forbid, deare Lord, that I ≈øhould euer think, that thou ha≈øt broken the Oath and Te≈øtament, which thou ha≈øt ≈øpoken to Abraham, I≈øaack, and Iacob, thy Seruants, ≈øaying; By my Gen. 22. ≈øelfe haue I ≈øworne, I will multiply thee, and I will multiply thy Seed as the Starres of Heauen, and as the Sand that is vpon the Sea ≈øhoare: Thy Seede ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Gates of his Enemies, and in thy Seede ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth. the Earth, that ≈øhalbe dilated to the Ea≈øt, and to the We≈øt, and to the North, and to the South: and in thee, and thy Seed, ≈øhalbe ble≈ø≈øed all the Tribes of the Earth.

O God of Heauen, I beleeue mo≈øt firmely, that the Chri≈øtians, dilated ouer the World, profe≈ø≈øing one Faith, are the Seed of Abraham, the Gen. 22. Children of thy Kingdome, the Wheat that thou did≈øt ≈øowe, the Mat. 1 ‚Ä¢ . div.head: CHAP. VIII. How our Catholike Faith is ≈øo founded vpon the Oathes and Promi≈øes of God, that it is not po≈ø≈øible for any man to be an Heretike, or Prote≈øtant, of any Sect, or ≈øort, without affirming in effect and deed, that God Almightie is periured and for≈øworne.
div.p:
OVR Catholike Faith, which Prote≈øtants call Papi≈øtrie, is not founded vpon Men, as Prote≈øtant Mini≈øters tell thee, but vpon two things immoueable, The Oath of God, and, That it is impo≈ø≈øible for God to lye. By my ≈øelfe Gen. 22. haue I ≈øworne, ≈øaith our Lord, I will multiply thee, and I will
multiply thy Seede as the Starres of Heauen, and as the ≈øand which is by the Sea-≈øhore: thy Seede ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Gates of his enemies, and in thy Seede ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth. Not only the Brittans, in an Iland, diuided from the whole World, but all the Nations of the Earth. The Scripture fore≈øeeing, that God Gal. 3. 8. iu≈øtifieth the Gentiles by Faith (by Faith, that worketh by Gal. 3. 22. Charitie) ≈øhewed vnto Abraham before, that in thee ≈øhall all Nations Gal. 5. 6. be ble≈ø≈øed. For God promi≈øing Heb. 6. 13. to Abraham, becau≈øe he had none greater by whom hee might ≈øweare, hee ≈øware by him≈øelfe; ≈øaying: Vnle≈ø≈øe ble≈ø≈øing, I ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe thee, and multiplying, ≈øhall multiply thee, &c. for men≈øweare by greater then them≈øelues, and
the end of all their controuer≈øie, for confirmation, is an oath: So God meaning more abundantly to ≈øhew the heires of the Promi≈øe the ≈øtabilitie of his Coun≈øell, hee interpo≈øed an Oath, that by two things vnmoueable, whereby it is impo≈ø≈øible for God to lye, wee may haue a mo≈øt ≈øtrong comfort, who haue fledde, to hold fa≈øt the Hope propo≈øed, That in the Seede of Abraham, our Sauiour, not one, or few Nations, but all the Families of the Earth Act. 3. 25. ≈øhould be ble≈ø≈øed.

Vpon the≈øe two things vnmoueable, are founded our Catholike Church, & holy Faith; the Oath of God, & That it is impo≈ø≈øible for God to ly, or violate his Oath & Promi≈øes; euery where ≈øpoken of in the Scriptures, to be fulfilled vpon Chri≈øtians,
beleeuing in our Lord and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, of the Seed of Dauid, of the Seed of Abraham, that in his Seed Gen. 22. Luc. 1. 55. ≈øhould be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth, as hee ≈øpake to our fathers, to Abraham and his Seed for euer.

So, that it is not po≈ø≈øible for any man, by any means, to become an Heretike, or Prote≈øtant, of any Sect or ≈øort, vnle≈ø≈øe he affirme in effect, and deeds, that God Almightie is a lyer, and for≈øworne; nor po≈ø≈øible for any man ≈øincerely to maintaine or defend in effect, and deeds, that God Almightie cannot lye, or be for≈øworn, but he mu≈øt be of that Religion which Prote≈øtants call Papi≈øtrie, doe what hee can.

Whereupon S. Paul ≈øayth, An Heretike ≈øinneth, being condemned 1. Tit. 3. 10. by his owne iudgement: For that he knoweth, that he preacheth again≈øt the Oathes and Promi≈øes of God; and pronounceth in his workes, and deeds, God Almightie to be for≈øworne, and a lyar: and hereupon our Sauiour ≈øayth, He that doth not beleeue, is alreadie iudged. Hee that will not beleeue God Almightie, when hee ≈øweareth, and reneweth his Oath ≈øo often as hee doth in the Scriptures; there are no meanes left to conuince him, but by Ari≈øtotles argument, viz. Puni≈øhment, and Paines: Tho≈øe who Li. 1. Top‚ñ™ ca. 9. doubt (≈øayth Ari≈øtotle) whether they ≈øhould honour the Gods, or no, ≈øtand in need of Paines.
And according to this, are the words of our Sauiour, where Luc. 16. 30. hee ≈øayth, If they heare not Moy≈øes, and the Prophets; neither if one ≈øhould ri≈øe from the dead, will they beleeue. Such as will not beleeue the Oathes of God Almightie, recorded by Moy≈øes, and the Prophets, there is no other meanes left, for to make them confe≈ø≈øe truth, but by eternall Torments.

Eua beleeued the Deuill, that God Almightie could lye, when he told her, No; you ≈øhall not die, whereas God Almightie Gen. 3. 4. had told her, that ≈øhee ≈øhould, if ≈øhe eate of the forbidden fruit; and by this meanes deceiuing her, hee depriued her and all her po≈øteritie of the Ioyes of Paradi≈øe,

Take thou example by thy Mothers fall, and doe not beleeue the Deuill, or Sectaries, when in effect and deeds they ≈øhall per≈øwade thee, that God Almightie can lye, or be for≈øworne, and ≈øuffer his Catholike Church to erre, faile, and decay, contrarie to his Oath and Promi≈øes; that they draw thee not from the Content and Happine≈ø≈øe of Grace in this life, and Glorie in the other, into the horror of all temporall Di≈øcontents, and after death, into eternall Torments.

Saint Augu≈øtine in his time vrged the Donati≈øts with this foundation of our Catholike Faith, the Oath of God, and the
Impo≈ø≈øibilitie for him to lye; ≈øaying to them, as wee, in his wordes, ≈øay now to Prote≈øtants; changing onely Donati≈øts for Elizabethians, and Africa for Brittanie.

p.hi: To you Elizabethians, the Catholike Church doth ≈øay: O ≈øonnes of men, how long are yee of heauie heart? Why doe you loue vanitie, and ≈øeeke after a Lye? Wherefore haue you diuided your ≈øelues, by a wicked ≈øacrilegious Schi≈øme, from the vnitie of the whole World?

div.p: Wherefore doe you beleeue, that the Cockle hath growne, and hath filled the World, and the Wheat to haue dimini≈øhed, in Brittanie onely to haue remained? Doe you call your ≈øelues Chri≈øtians, and yet contradict Chri≈øt. Hee ≈øaith, ≈øuffer both to grow vntill the Harue≈øt. Hee did not ≈øay, let the Cockle grow, and the Wheat dimini≈øh, Hee ≈øaid, the Field is the World, and did not ≈øay, the Field is Brittanie. Thus Saint Augu≈øtine, Epi≈øt. 171. and we with him.

So deare Reader, not to liue, ≈øeeking after lyes, and publikely profe≈ø≈øing in deeds and actions, that God Almightie is for≈øworne; when Sathan ≈øhall tempt thee in matters of Faith; or any controuer≈øie ari≈øeth betweene thee & ≈øome Prote≈øtant, about Religion; as about the Reall Pre≈øence, Prayer for the Dead, Interce≈ø≈øion to Saints, &c. make ≈øome of the afore≈øaid Acts, ≈øet downe in the former Chapter, with zeale and feruor; and hold fa≈øt the hope propo≈øed, which Heb. 6. 18. wee haue as an Anchor of the Soule, ≈øure and firme, the Oath of God, and that it is impo≈ø≈øible for God to lye. Heb. 6. 17. God meaning more abundantly to ≈øhew the heires of his Promi≈øe the ≈øtabilitie of his Coun≈øell, in performing what hee did promi≈øe; for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of the hearts of men, in the infallibilitie of our Chri≈øtian Catholike Faith, Church, & Prie≈øthood, ≈øwore two Oathes; the one, in confirmation of the Prie≈øthood

Of multiplying Gen. 22. his Seed as the Starres of Heauen, and as the ≈øand that is by the Sea-≈øhoare: Thy Seed ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the gates of his enemies: In thy Seed ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Families of the Earth. And ≈øecondly, by winning Men to deny in action and deeds, that our Lord was a Prie≈øt for euer, according to the Order of Melchi≈øedeck; and mouing them to affirme in acts and

And ≈øo by mouing men in acts & deeds, publikely to profe≈ø≈øe, that God Almightie hath beene twice for≈øworn; the Diuel hath founded and planted among≈øt them his new reformed Religions, grouÃÑ ded and founded vpon two coÃÑtradictories to the grounds of our Catholike Faith: viz. God Almightie cannot lye, or be forw≈øorne; God Almighty is periured, and can lye.

Which is ≈øo manife≈øt, that if Malice and Pa≈ø≈øion doe not blinde thy heart, and

For graunt me but that God Almightie cannot be for≈øworne nor violate his Oaths; and in euery opinion of Faith and Religion, as a creature of God Almighties, maintaine in act and deed, that he cannot be periured or for≈øworne; and thou cau≈øt not be a Prote≈øtant of any Sect or ≈øort, by any means po≈ø≈øible; but of nece≈ø≈øitie be of that Faith and Religion Prote≈øtants call Papi≈øtrie.

As for example; the que≈øtion is, whether our Catholike Church, or your Prote≈øtant Congregation, bee the true Church of God. Let vs goe to the Oath of God, and as creatures
of God Almightie, let vs in actions and deeds firmely and faithfully beleeue this Oath of God to Abraham to be true, and ≈øubmit our vnder≈øtandings and iudgements vnto it, as vnto the mo≈øt infallible and mo≈øt certaine truth that can be: and as willing to honour God without pa≈ø≈øion or malice, let vs ≈øimply ≈øeeke whether this Oath of God (By my ≈øelfe haue I ≈øworne, I will ble≈ø≈øe thee, and will multiply thy Seed as the Starres of Heauen, and as the Sand that is by the Sea ≈øhoare: Thy Seede ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Gates of his Enemies, and in thy Seede ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed all the Nations of the Earth) be more verified vpon our Catholike Church, or your Prote≈øtant Congregation.

Fir≈øt, for Temporall ble≈ø≈øings, all the Chri≈øtian Kings and Kingdomes, that euer haue beene flouri≈øhing vpon the face of the Earth, before Henrie the eight, were ≈øo Catholike, that thou can≈øt not name me one, who was in Faith and Religion a Prote≈øtant, and held the Religion Prote≈øtants now maintaine.

And whether the Seede of Prote≈øtants, or Seede of Catholikes, haue beene multiplied as the Sand that is by the Sea-≈øhore, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the Gates of their enemies; not only all the Chronicles and Hi≈øtories of Countries and Nations, doe beare witne≈ø≈øe for vs; but euen Prote≈øtants them≈øelues; conuinced with truth, doe confe≈ø≈øe it: Perkins vpon the Creede, pag. 307. affirmeth, That during the ≈øpace of nine hundreth yeares, the Popi≈øh Here≈øie hath ≈øpread it ≈øelfe ouer the whole Earth. Fulke in his Treati≈øe again≈øt Stapleton, pag. 25. affirmeth, That ≈øome Prote≈øtants haue written, that the

div.head: CHAP. IX. That hope in God is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to the Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe of Man, but not only Hope, without other vertues. And how acts of Hope made by Catholikes, include Sacraments, and other Vertues, and not exclude them.
div.p: THat it is impo≈ø≈øible to be ≈øaued, or finde Content without hope in God, is manife≈øt by rea≈øon.

Secondly, it is manife≈øt by the Scriptures, which in plain tearms affirme, That by Hope we Rom 8. 39. Rom. 15. 4. are ≈øaued. Againe, What things ≈øoeuer haue beene written to our learning, they haue beene written, that by the patience and con≈øolatiof the Scriptures wee may haue Hope. So Saint Paul ≈øaith, The Rom. 15. 13. God of Hope repleni≈øh you with all

Againe, They that tru≈øt in P≈ø. 33. 9. our Lord, as Mount Sion, he ≈øhall not be moued for euer. Againe, Ble≈ø≈øed is that man that hopeth in P≈ø. 36. 4. God. But as wee ≈øaid before, of onely Faith; that Faith, without other vertues, is dead to Grace in this life, and Glorie in the other, and ≈øerueth ≈øuch as haue it, for nothing but for the increa≈øe of eternall torments: ≈øo al≈øo it is manife≈øt,
that onely Hope, without other vertues, is a vaine and dead Hope; without any true Content in this life, or in all eternitie; as is manife≈øt fir≈øt by rea≈øon.
Becau≈øe Hope endeth with Death: ≈øo if the Content and Happine≈ø≈øe of Man ≈øhould con≈øi≈øt in onely Hope, there ≈øhould be no Content in the other life.

Secondly, we ≈øee (≈øome few excepted, who fall into vtter de≈øpaire) that all men, of all Sects and ≈øorts, and how wicked ≈øoeuer, hope for Happine≈ø≈øe, and Content: So, if Hope, without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of other vertues, were ≈øufficient to Happine≈ø≈øe, men might be happie and wretched both together; which is contrarie to experience.
Thirdly, to hope for Happine≈ø≈øe, is not to be happie; ≈øince none hopeth for that he hath, but enioyeth. Whereby is manife≈øt, that onely Hope is not ≈øufficient to be happie.

Againe, the Scriptures ≈øay, Not euerie one that ≈øaith, Lord, Mat. 7. 21. Lord, ≈øhall enter into the Kingdome of Heauen, but he that doth the will of my Father which is in Heauen. Whereby is manife≈øt, that the Promi≈øes are not made to a dead Hope, which is void of other vertues, but to ≈øuch a Hope, as is conioint to all other vertues, and is void of all iniquitie.

Heere thou maye≈øt ob≈øerue, deere Reader, the error of many Prote≈øtants; who being driuen from the impious Doctrine of Iu≈øtification

div.head: Acts of Hope.

div.head: CHAP. X. That Charitie, or loue of God, together with Faith and Hope, is nece≈ø≈øarie to the Content and Happine≈ø≈øe of Man.
div.p: THat it is not po≈ø≈øible for Man to be content, and happie, without the loue of God, is manife≈øt by the light of Rea≈øon.

Paul) Prophecie, and know all Mi≈øteries, and all Knowledge, and I ≈øhould haue all Faith, ≈øo that I could remoue Mountaines, and haue not Charitie, I am nothing; and if I ≈øhould di≈øtribute all my goods, for meat for the poore, and if I ≈øhould deliuer my bodie, ≈øo that I burne, and haue not Charitie, it doth profit me nothing.
