Whereby is manife≈øt, that the Scribes preached faithfull and true Doctrine; otherwi≈øe our Sauiour would not haue wi≈øhed their Auditors, to ob≈øerue and doe what≈øoeuer they ≈øaid: But they wanted Charitie, in them≈øelues, to doe good Workes, and keepe the Law; as witne≈ø≈øeth our Sauiour, ≈øaying, But according Mat. 23. ‚Ä¢ . to their workes doe yee not; for they ≈øay, and doe not: and ≈øo, for want of Charitie, or loue towards God, they ≈øhall not (as our Sauiour ≈øayth) enter into the Kingdome of Heauen; or euer enioy Re≈øt, or Happine≈ø≈øe, but endle≈ø≈øe Paines.

Againe, our Sauiour ≈øayth, If God were your Father, verily Io. 8. 42. you would loue me, for from God I proceed. Whereby our Sauiour giueth vs to vnder≈øtand, that ≈øuch as doe not loue God with all their hearts, according to the Commaundement, haue not God for their Father, and are not the ≈øonnes of God, but of the Deuill: As in another place he ≈øayth, You are of your Father the Deuill, and the de≈øires Io. 8. 43. of your Father you will doe: who though he beleeue that there is a God, as S. Iames witne≈ø≈øeth; Iam. 2. yet hee doth not loue God with all his heart, and keepe his Commandements. Whereupon it is written of our Sauiour, That for this appeared 1. Io. 3. 8. the Sonne of God, that he
might di≈ø≈øolue the workes of the Deuill; bring men to loue God Almightie vvith all their hearts, and winne them to keepe his Law: and ≈øo ≈øaith of the reprobate Iewes, I haue Io. 5. 42. knowne you, that the loue of God you haue not in you: And of the elect Apo≈øtles, You haue Io. 16. 27. loued me.

Loue being the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Rom. 13. 19. Law, the want of loue, is the worke of the Deuill, in the hearts of all the wicked; and the loue of God, the workes of our Lord, in the hearts of the elect. Whereupon our Sauiour ≈øaith, Verily, verily, I Io. 8. 15. ≈øay vnto you, if any man keepe my word, hee ≈øhall not ≈øee death for euer: and yet againe ≈øaith, He that loueth me not, keepeth not my words. So, loue God Almightie
with all thy heart, and thou ≈øhalt not ≈øee death for euer. He that loueth not, abideth in Io 3. 14. death; dead to Grace in this life, and to Glorie in the other.

By which is manife≈øt, that happie life cannot be, without the louing of God Almightie with all our hearts: In≈øomuch, as if thou hadde≈øt Happine≈ø≈øe and Content, and yet didde≈øt not loue it with all thy heart, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not be happie; as witne≈ø≈øeth S. Augu≈øtine, ≈øaying, He is not De Ciuitat. li. 14. ca. 15. happie, of whom happie life is not beloued: Which thou maye≈øt find true by experience; ≈øeeing thy ≈øelfe, and all others, to take comfort and content in that which they loue, and not in that which
they neglect. Whereupon S. Paul ≈øayth, If any man loue not 1. Cor. 16. 2. our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, be he Anathema; his bodie cut off from the communion of the Catholike Church vpon earth, and his ≈øoule excluded from the ioyes of Heauen.

div.head: CHAP. XI. How to attaine vnto the loue of God, and how to loue his diuine Maie≈øtie with all our hearts.
div.p: SEeing that Diuine Loue, or Charitie, is nece≈ø≈øarie to the Content and Happine≈ø≈øe of Man, it is requi≈øite al≈øo to ≈øet downe the meanes, by which thou maye≈øt attaine vnto this Diuine Loue, or Charitie, that thou maye≈øt be happie.

Charitie (≈øaith S. Paul) is 1. Tim. 1. 15. from a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained. So, that the fir≈øt thing which thou oughte≈øt to doe, if thou de≈øire to loue God Almightie with all thy heart; is to ≈øeparate thy ≈øelfe for a time from all other affaires and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, onely to attend vnto the examining of thy Con≈øcience, how thou ha≈øt ≈øpent thy life pa≈øt; and to call to minde all thy cuill thoughts, words, deeds, and vniu≈øt actions, which haue ≈øtayned and made filthie thy heart and ≈øoule; to confe≈ø≈øe them, with contrition and ≈øorrow, to one of the Pa≈øtors of the Church of God, to whom God Almightie hath giuen authoritie to forgiue ≈øinnes,
≈øaying, Who≈øe ≈øinnes you ≈øhall forgiue, Io. 20. 23. they are forgiuen; that thy ≈øinnes being forgiuen, thou maye≈øt haue a cleane and pure heart, fit to receiue Diuine Loue, or Charitie; and God Almightie will be≈øtow it vpon thee, according to his Word, ≈øaying, Returne to me, and I Mat 3. 7. will returne to you.

No bodie putteth new Wine Mat. 9. 17. into old Bottles, otherwi≈øe the Bottles peri≈øh: But new Wine they put into new Bottles, and both are pre≈øerued together. So, if thou wilt receiue the new Wine of Diuine Loue, and Charitie, thou mu≈øt fir≈øt lay away thy old Conuer≈øation, Eph. 4. 22. the old Man, which is corrupted according to the de≈øires of Error; thy ≈øelfe-loue, proper iudgement, priuate ≈øpirit,
inordinate appetites, and pa≈ø≈øions, and by ≈øorrow for thy ≈øinnes, and Penance, be renued in the ≈øpirit of thy mind, and put on the new Man, which according to God, is created in Iu≈øtice, and holine≈ø≈øe of the Truth. Whereupon Saint Iohn Bapti≈øt, ≈øpeaking of the way, or meanes, how to attaine vnto Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, ≈øayth, Who hath ≈øhewed Mat. 3. 7. you to flye from the wrath to come? yeeld therefore fruit worthie of Penance. Which is as if he ≈øhould haue ≈øaid; If any one hath ≈øhewed you the way to Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, and not by contrition, and dete≈øtation of ≈øinne, the fruites of Penance; hee hath deceiued you. So our Lord and Sauiour,
in his fir≈øt Sermon according to Saint Matthew, taught Penance, as the fir≈øt meanes to Happine≈ø≈øe; the Text ≈øaying, that Mat. 4. 17. Ie≈øus began to preach, and to ≈øay, Doe Penance, for the Kingdome of God is at hand.

Heere thou maye≈øt ≈øee, how many men, which are of ≈øhort Capacities, and weake and ≈øhallow Wits, and Vnder≈øtandings, are deceiued; in framing to them≈øelues a conceit, that to doe Penance, is to be tormented, deiected, and oppre≈ø≈øed in minde; when it is nothing le≈ø≈øe: but the greate≈øt ea≈øe, remedie, and re≈øt, to a deiected and oppre≈ø≈øed minde, that can be had, or found; and the way, and meanes, to
all true Content and Happine≈ø≈øe. If thou wilt beleeue the Scriptures, and Experience; Contrition, or ≈øorrow for ≈øinne, doth much differ from the ≈øorrow, or lamenting of worldly men; when out of ≈øelfe-loue, they lament the lo≈ø≈øe of their worldly Commodities, or Plea≈øures. The fruites of this Sorrow, are Sadne≈ø≈øe, Oppre≈ø≈øion of Minde, and Di≈øcontent, as being inordinate, and not ordained by God to be v≈øed as a meanes of finding Happine≈ø≈øe: vvhereas Penance, Contrition, and Sorrow for Sinnes, beeing meanes ordained by God, to Content and Happine≈ø≈øe; the more thou v≈øe≈øt them, the more re≈øt, and content of heart,
thou ≈øhalt finde; becau≈øe God Almightie doth reuiue the I≈øa. 57. 15. heart of the Contrite, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øting of the holy Gho≈øt, Gal 5. who≈øe fruits are Charitie, Ioy of heart, and Peace of minde; of which wee are to ≈øpeake more in his place.

A ≈øecond meanes of attayning vnto the loue of God, is often to Communicate, according to the words of our Lord, ≈øaying; He that eateth Ioh. 6. my Fle≈øh, and drinketh my Bloud, abideth in me, and I in him: which is the Charitie wee ≈øeeke for.

A third meanes, is Meditation; ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider all the benefits thou ha≈øt receiued from his diuine Maie≈øtie; as, Creation, Redemption, Con≈øeruation, and what≈øoeuer
graces thou ha≈øt, or expecte≈øt; and likewi≈øe, to meditate often vpon his diuine Attributes, as his infinite Goodne≈ø≈øe, Beautie, Maie≈øtie, and Power, &c. for the onely meanes to loue any thing that is very good, faire, plea≈øing, and beautifull; is but to looke ≈øeriou≈øly vpon it, and con≈øider it well, and the loue or liking of it pre≈øently is begotten in thy heart. And it being excellently good, the more thou thinke≈øt, or meditate≈øt vpon it, the more the loue of it increa≈øeth in thee. So if thou wilt loue much GOD Almightie, doe not omit thy Meditations.

A fourth meanes is, alwaies
to keepe the Pre≈øence of God; that hauing alwayes before thine eyes an infinite Good, from whom all things el≈øe borrow what≈øoeuer good they haue; thou can≈øt not but little e≈øteeme of all other goods, in compari≈øon of it, and loue it with thy whole heart, and all things el≈øe, as they may conduct thee vnto it: of which Pre≈øence wee are to ≈øpeake in our third Booke.

A fifth meanes is, to make many Acts of the loue of God: As in Arts and Sciences, thy continuall practi≈øe increa≈øeth thy knowledge and skill; ≈øo the making of many Acts of the loue of God, increa≈øeth
in thee the loue of God: And to that end, heere I ≈øet downe the≈øe Acts following.

div.head: Acts of Charitie, or Loue towards God.
div.p: AS the cha≈øed Hart thir≈øteth after the Fountaine of Water; ≈øo I de≈øire, that my heart ≈øhould perpetually thir≈øt after thee, deare Lord.

O Lord of infinite beautie, that my heart were ≈øo wounded with thy loue, that out of feruour of ≈øpirit, I might in ≈øilent ≈øpeech, perpetually breath forth, When ≈øhall I come and appeare before thy face.

O mo≈øt amiable Sonne of the liuing God, take now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this my heart, which
was created for to loue thee; and pierce it with a thou≈øand wounds of pure loue, that I may for euer ≈øweetly langui≈øh after thy eternall beautie.
How beloued are thy Tabernacles, O Lord of Ho≈øts: my ≈øoule coueteth and fainteth after the Courts of my God.
Decre Ie≈øu, to thee I con≈øecrate my heart.
O deere King of all beautie and glory, I will no other inheritance but thee.
O Life of my life, and more beautifull then all beauties created, put together; inflame me with a mo≈øt de≈øired burning after thy eternall beautie.

O Lord of infinite mercy, how great are the multitude
of thy mercies; that thou commande≈øt mee to loue thee; and if I doe not, thou art angrie, and threatene≈øt eternall mi≈øeries: when in louing thee, con≈øi≈øteth all my ioyes and good.
O who will giue to me my Lord, that I may die for thee; that by my corporall death my ≈øoule may be ingulfed in thee, her re≈øt, and cha≈øt bed-Chamber of all diuine delights.

Too late haue I loued thee, Beautie, ≈øo ancient and ≈øo new; too late haue I loued thee: but pardon my negligence pa≈øt, deere Lord, and graunt, that this my beginning may la≈øt, and increa≈øe for euer.

Thou, deere Lord, was within
mee, and I was without my ≈øelfe; and among≈øt the≈øe faire things which thou ha≈øt created, I ≈øought thee, and fowly erred: faire they were becau≈øe thou created≈øt them, but to me foule; for that I loued them, and loued them not in thee.

O how I lament, deere Lord, that my poore ≈øoule hath beene ≈øo deceiued with ≈øen≈øuall loue, and worldly vanitie: now conuert mee ≈øo wholly vnto thee, deere Lord, that nothing created may plea≈øe me, but the only louing of thy diuine Maie≈øtie.
Thou art all faire, my Loue, thou art all faire, and there is not a ≈øpot or ≈øtaine in thee.
O my infinite Good, I re≈øigne to thee all that thy liberalitie hath be≈øtowed vpon me; that thereby I may plea≈øe thee, and offer without cea≈øing, in the Altar of my heart, my ≈øelfe in Sacrifice.

If I forget to loue thee, my Lord, let all my plea≈øures be turned into ≈øorrowes; and let my right hand be forgetfull of her actions, if I doe not offer vnto thee, vpon the Altar of my heart, a Sacrifice of perpetuall Loue, Morning, Midday, and Euening.

div.head: CHAP. XII. That true Content and Happine≈ø≈øe cannot be without Charitie, or loue towards our neighbours, and keeping of the Commandements of God.
div.p:
SO great is the Obligation and bond of Societie, interpo≈øed betweene all things created; that the good of one, in ≈øome ≈øort, dependeth vpon the loue and ≈øocietie with the other: The Angels in Heauen reioice one at anothers good and Happine≈ø≈øe, and receiue increa≈øe of Content, by the increa≈øe of Glory be≈øtowed vpon any one: The Heauens ≈øend downe ≈øhowers and dew, to water and make
plea≈øant the Earth; and the Earth ≈øhooteth vp all her fruits towards the Heauens, as though ≈øhe would, in gratitude, offer them to the Heauens, as a Pre≈øent, for all benefits receiued. The Elements liue in a perpetuall interchange of amitie; the Fire tran≈øporting it ≈øelfe into Ayre, the Ayre into Water, and the Water into Earth; and the Earth conden≈øing and becomming hard, returneth againe to yeeld Fire; and their intercour≈øe of friend≈øhip is confirmed in ≈øo firme a league, that rather then the Earth ≈øhould in any thing peri≈øh by ≈øuffering vacuum; the Ayre, or Fire, forgetfull of his owne well, and content; of his owne will and
de≈øire, leaueth his Region, to de≈øcend in ha≈øt to ≈øupply the Earths want, that vacuum bee not found in Nature. The mo≈øt vntame Birds, and ≈øauage Bea≈øts, keepe companie together, each one reioycing at others good; In≈øomuch, as that the wilde Boare, or Beare, who among≈øt the bea≈øts are accompted the mo≈øt ≈øauage, will not ≈øticke to turne again≈øt Man, vvhen hee ≈øhall perceiue that he hath hurt or wounded any of his companie. So ≈øtrait is the bond of Amitie betweene all liuing things, in their kinde, that the weale of one ≈øeemeth, in ≈øome ≈øort, to be the content of all.

And as for Man, the greater he is, the more neede he ≈øtandeth of the common people: Kings there could be none if Common people were not; nor yet Common people liue long in vnitie and peace, if Kings they had not: Princes and Peeres depend vpon their meane≈øt Subiects; and their Subiects liue in peace, vnder the Protection of their greatne≈ø≈øe. So Nature hath combined all in vnity and friend≈øhip; that he mu≈øt be a mon≈øter in nature, that ≈øhould deny the loue of his Neighbour to be nece≈ø≈øary to his Content and Happine≈ø≈øe.

Againe, ≈øome are ≈øo yong, that they cannot helpe them≈øelues; ≈øome ≈øo old, that their forces are ≈øpent; ≈øome in Pri≈øon;
many lame; and none ≈øo exqui≈øite in all Arts and Sciences, that he is able completely to furni≈øh him≈øelfe with what≈øoeuer he wanteth: Whereby appeareth, that there is nothing more manife≈øt, then that the loue of our Neighbour is nece≈ø≈øary to Mans Happine≈ø≈øe.

And it is no le≈ø≈øe manife≈øt by the Scriptures, and light of Grace, that the loue of our Neighbours is nece≈ø≈øarie to Content and Happine≈ø≈øe; He that ≈øaith he is in the Light, Io. 2. 9. and hateth his brother, is in the Darkene≈ø≈øe, euen vntill now. Hee that loueth his brother, abideth in the Light, and ≈øcandall is not in him: But he that hateth his brother, is in darkene≈ø≈øe, and walketh in the darkene≈ø≈øe,
and knoweth not whither hee goeth, becau≈øe the Darkene≈ø≈øe hath blinded his eies. Againe, Euery one Io. 3. 10. that is not iu≈øt, is not of God, and he that loueth not his brother; becau≈øe this is the Annuntiation which you haue heard from the beginning, That you loue one another. Againe, Who≈øoeuer hateth his 1. Io. 3. 16. brother, is a Murtherer, and you know, that no Murtherer hath life euerla≈øting abiding in him. Againe, My deare≈øt, 1. Io. 4. 7. let vs loue one another, becau≈øe Charitie is of God, and euery one that loueth, is borne of God, and knoweth God; He that loueth not, knoweth not God. If any man ≈øhall ≈øay, that I loue God, and hateth his brother, he is a lyar; for he
that loueth not his brother whom he ≈øeeth, God, whom he ≈øeeth not, how can hee loue? And this is the Commandement we haue from God, That hee which loueth God, loueth al≈øo his brother: whereby, and by many more pa≈ø≈øages of holy Scriptures, it is manife≈øt, that the loue of our Neighbour, is nece≈ø≈øarie to Happine≈ø≈øe, and Saluation; and that no man what≈øoeuer, ≈øhall either in this World, or in all Eternitie, euer attaine vnto any true Content, or Happine≈ø≈øe, who doth not keep the Law, or tenne Commandements, which con≈øi≈øt in the loue of God, and loue of our Neighbour, as witne≈ø≈øeth our Lord, ≈øaying, Thou ≈øhalt loue the Lord
thy God from thy whole heart, Mat. 22. 37. and with thy whole ≈øoule, and with thy whole minde. This is the greate≈øt, and the fir≈øt Commandement; And the ≈øecond is like to this, Thou ≈øhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelfe: on the≈øe two Commandements dependeth the whole Law, and the Prophets. So Saint Paul ≈øaith; Hee that loueth his Rom. 13. 9. Neighbour, hath fulfilled the Law: For thou ≈øhalt not commit Adulterie. Thou ≈øhalt not Kill. Thou ≈øhalt not Steale. Thou ≈øhalt not beare Fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe. Thou ≈øhalt not Couet. And if there be any other Commandement, it is comprehended in this word; Thou ≈øhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelfe. The loue of thy Neighbour worketh no euill. Againe,
All the Law is fulfilled in one Gal. 5. 14. word, Thou ≈øhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelfe.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The meanes how to become heartie wel-willers of our ≈øeuere≈øt Per≈øecutors, and mo≈øt alienated Aduer≈øaries.
div.p:
ALthough it be ea≈øie to loue men of meeke and milde di≈øpo≈øition; yet it may ≈øeeme hard, heartily to loue, and pray for our enemies and per≈øecutors: e≈øpecially for ≈øuch per≈øecutors, as haue for office, to draw vs (by ≈øpoile of goods, lo≈ø≈øe of libertie, and life) from temporall and eternall Happine≈ø≈øe, into
temporall and eternall My≈øerie; which is the ca≈øe of our Per≈øecution in England: wherefore it is nece≈ø≈øarie heere to ≈øet downe the meanes, how to loue our mo≈øt alienated enemies, or aduer≈øaries, and fulfill the Precept of our Lord, which ≈øaith, Loue your enemies, doe Mat. 5. 44. good to them that hate you, pray for them that per≈øecute and abu≈øe you, that you may be the Children of your Father which is in Heauen, who maketh his Sunne to ≈øhine vpon the good and bad, and raineth vpon the iu≈øt and vniu≈øt. Againe, Reuenge not your ≈øelues, Rom. 12. 19, my deere≈øt, but giue place vnto Wrath; for it is written, Reuenge to me; I will reward, ≈øaith our Lord: but if thy
enemy hunger, giue him meate, if he thir≈øt, giue him drinke; be not ouercome with euill, but ouercome in good, the euill. If, ≈øaith the Prophet Dauid, I haue rendred to them that repayed me euill; let me worthily fall emptie from mine enemies. Let the enemie per≈øecute P≈ø. 7. 6. my ≈øoule, and take and treade downe my life in the Earth, and bring downe my glory in the du≈øt.

The practi≈øe of which Doctrine, though to worldly men it ≈øeeme hard, and haue great difficultie; yet by the grace of God, and the good meanes which he hath left for vs to v≈øe, it is light and ea≈øie: Of our ≈øelues, as 2. Cor. 3. 4. of our ≈øelues, we be not ≈øufficient to thinke any thing. But
our ≈øufficiencie is of God: Chri≈øt Rom. 8. 34. Ie≈øus that dyed (for vs) who is on the right hand of God, al≈øo maketh interce≈ø≈øion for vs: Who then ≈øhall ≈øeperate vs from the Charitie of Chri≈øt? Tribulation? or Di≈øtre≈ø≈øe? or Famine? or Nakedne≈ø≈øe? or Danger? or Per≈øecution? or the Sword? (as it is written) For we are killed for thy ≈øake all the day, we are e≈øteemed as ≈øheepe of ≈ølaughter. But in all the≈øe things we ouercome, becau≈øe of him that hath loued vs. I can all things (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) Phi. 4. in him that comforteth mee. Comfort vs, O Lord, and wee can doe all things; yea, loue our heauie≈øt Per≈øecutors, as our ≈øelues.

Since from God Almightie
proceedeth all our good, and ≈øtrength: the fir≈øt means of atteining vnto the loue of our Per≈øecutors, as our ≈øelues; is much to loue his Diuine Maie≈øtie: To them Rom. 8. that loue God, all things cooperate in good. Againe, If any Io. 14. 23. loue me, he will keepe my word, (loue his Enemies, and pray for his Per≈øecutors) Loue is Cant. 8. 6. as ≈øtrong as Death: The Loue of God nothing can ouercome; Many Waters (of tribulation) Cant. 8. cannot quench Charitie, neither ≈øhall Flouds (of Per≈øecution) ouerwhelme it. Wherefore the fir≈øt meanes, is much to loue God Almightie, and often to make the afore≈øaid Acts of Loue, and Charitie, towards God, ≈øet downe in the eleuenth
Chapter, and then thou wilt ea≈øily loue thy mo≈øt alienated enemies with all thy heart.

The ≈øecond meanes is, often to reflect vpon the prouidence of God Almightie; who ≈øince hee intendeth to crowne none, but ≈øuch as 2. Tim. 2. ≈øhall ouercome in combate; fir≈øt giueth the grace and force to ouercome, and then permitteth my≈øerable people to practi≈øe cruelties and per≈øecutions vpon thee; that thou, by his grace, ouercomming them, and remaining, through Patience and Charitie, a Conquerour, he may crowne thee with abundance of temporall Content in this life, and after death, in the other, with eternall
glory, according to the words of S. Iames, ≈øaying; Ble≈ø≈øed is the man that ≈øuffereth Iam‚ñ™ 1. 12. temptation; for when he hath beene proued, he ≈øhall receiue the Crowne of life, which God hath promi≈øed to them that loue him. In≈øomuch, as by ouercomming, thy gaine is ≈øo great, that if a per≈øecuting King, Prince, or Potentate, ≈øhould ≈øpoile him≈øelfe of his Scepter and Crowne, and be≈øtow them both on thee, together with his Kingdome; yet, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt not receiue by his meanes, ≈øo great a benefit, as the Martyr whoÃÑ he putteth to death either publikely, or by long priuate impri≈øonment, or other di≈øtre≈ø≈øes for our Catholike Faith: My Num. 23. 10. ≈øoule die the death of the iu≈øt, and
my la≈øt ende be made like to them.

So in truth and veritie, there is no cau≈øe, why thou ≈øhoulde≈øt hate or wi≈øh any euill vnto thy ≈øeuere≈øt Per≈øecutors; but much cau≈øe, why thou ≈øhoulde≈øt wi≈øh well vnto them, and loue them tenderly: ≈øince that by their meanes, and by their lo≈ø≈øe, both of temporall and eternall Content and Happine≈ø≈øe; thou, per≈øeuering in Charitie, art to receiue a greater benefit then otherwi≈øe thou coulde≈øt expect euer to haue receiued, viz. to be crowned with a Crown of Apoc. 3. 10. eternall glory, to re≈øt in the ioy of our Lord, before the throne of God, and ≈øerue him Apoc. 7. day and night in his Temple, and
be conducted by the Lambe, our Sauiour, to the liuing Fountaines of Waters.

And for this cau≈øe, the wi≈øe≈øt men that be vpon the face of the Earth, haue a pious enuie at our happine≈ø≈øe here in England, For that we are killed P≈ø. 43. 22. all the day, we are e≈øteemed as Sheepe of ≈ølaughter, for the Catholike Faith, which wee profe≈ø≈øe; and goe continually, as the Prophet Dauid ≈øayth, With our liues alwayes P≈ø. 118. in our hands, to offer them to God Almightie in Sacrifice; knowing, that our reward is very great in Heauen: for ≈øo Mat. 5. 12. they per≈øecuted the Prophets, Apo≈øtles, and Martyrs, that were before vs: To whom our Sauiour ≈øayth; You are they that haue remained with
me, in my temptations; and I di≈øpo≈øe to you, as my Father di≈øpo≈øed to me, a Kingdome, that Luc. 22. 28. you may eate and drinke vpon my Table, and in my Kingdome, and may ≈øit vpon Thrones, iudging the twelue Tribes of I≈ørael.

Thou ≈øee≈øt what labour, paines, and dangers, euerie worldly man would be content to take, if he might but hope to a≈øcend vp to be an earthly King, or Prince, or come to attaine ≈øome grace and fauour in the Court; where, in truth and veritie, their greate≈øt Plea≈øures are mixt with ≈øo many Woes, that if they would but looke vpon them with rea≈øon, they haue more cau≈øe to lament their euill mi≈øhap, then to
take glorie in their ≈øeeming high e≈øtate. How much more ≈øhoulde≈øt thou be content, gladly, and willingly, to ≈øuffer ≈øome ≈øeuen yeares paines, and per≈øecution, in hope to enioy the Kingdome of Heauen, the glorie of the other life, and that eternally.

A third meanes is, to ≈øtirre vp and reuiue thy Faith in thee, by making many Acts of Faith, founded vpon the Promi≈øes, to patient ≈øuffering Iniuries, and Per≈øecutions, for the loue thou beare≈øt to God; as often to make the≈øe or the like Acts.

p.hi: He that will ≈øaue his life,
≈øhall lo≈øe it, and he that ≈øhall lo≈øe his life for me, ≈øhall finde it.
What doth it profit a man, if
he gaine the whole world, and ≈øu≈øtaine the dammage of his Soule.

div.p: What permutation ≈øhall a man Mar. 26. giue for his Soule? What wilt thou take, that the Deuill may haue thy Soule, for to burne in Hell eternally? and trie but for a quarter of an houre, how thou can≈øt endure thy hand, or foot, to be burnt in this fire, vpon Earth? And then thou wilt laud the mercies of our Lord, that by his Grace, and thy ≈øuffering patiently ≈øo little paines; he hath ordained, to redeeme thee from eternall Torments.

p.hi: Wee ≈øuffer with Chri≈øt Ie≈øu,
that we may be glorified al≈øo with him.
The ≈øufferings of this time are not condigne to the glorie to
come, that ≈øhall be reuealed in vs.
Our tribulation, which is momentarie,
and light, worketh aboue mea≈øure exceedingly, an eternall weight of glorie in vs. If
wee be dead in Chri≈øt, then wee ≈øhall liue al≈øo together with him. If we ≈øhall ≈øu≈øtaine, we ≈øhall al≈øo reigne together.

div.p: So to liue by Faith, according as it is written: The iu≈øt Gal. 3. 12. liueth by Faith; for without Faith it is impo≈ø≈øible to plea≈øe God: For hee that commeth to God, Heb. 11. 6. mu≈øt beleeue, that hee is, and is a rewarder of them that ≈øeeke him.

And this is the Faith of the Saints; ≈øo renowmed, and often ≈øpoken of in the Scriptures:
the Faith of Henoch, Noe, Abraham, I≈øaac, Iacob, Io≈øeph, Moy≈øes, Gedeon, Barac, Samp≈øon, Iephte, (and the Apo≈øtles) who by Faith ouercame Kingdomes, wrought Iu≈øtice, obtained Promi≈øes, ≈øtopped the mouth of Lyons, extingui≈øhed the force of Fire, repelled the edge of the Sword, recouered of their Infirmities, had triall of Mockeries, and Stripes, of Bonds, and Pri≈øons, were Stoned, Hewed, Tempted, dying in ≈ølaughter of the Sword, went about in Sheepe skinnes, and Goats skinnes, needie in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, afflicted, of whom the World was not worthie, wandering in De≈øarts, in Mountaines, and Dennes, and in Caues in the Earth. As thou ≈øee≈øt, Religious men, and Prie≈øts, and Lay Catholikes
doe, in the time of this our per≈øecution in England; who firmely grounded and founded in the infallible certainetie of the Oathes and Promi≈øes of God, doe thinke what≈øoeuer they can ≈øuffer, or endure, in this life, too little to manife≈øt the con≈øtancie of their Faith, and Hope, in the Promi≈øes of God; that as S. Paul writeth of the Romans, ≈øo wee may ≈øay of the Engli≈øh Catholikes, Your Faith Rom. 1. 8. is renowmed throughout the whole World, and will be, in all Ages, in this life, and after death, for all eternitie, in Heauen.

A fourth may be, to remember, that it is the Precept of our Lord, ≈øaying, Loue your enemies, doe good to Mat. 5. 44.
them that hate you, pray for them that per≈øecute you, and abu≈øe you.

Thou ≈øee≈øt what paines the Pur≈øuinants take, at the commaundement of their May≈øters, to apprehend, take, ≈øpoyle, and torment Prie≈øts, and Catholikes; and in all equitie, it mu≈øt needes be a great ≈øhame vnto thee, that the commaundement of a Man ≈øhould haue more force to moue men to breake the commaundements of God, then the commaundement of God hath to moue thee, to keepe them; e≈øpecially con≈øidering, that all which they can get, is but to diuide the ≈øpoyles betweene their May≈øters and them, and the good countenance of their May≈øters
to them≈øelues: And thou expecte≈øt the Kingdome of Heauen, the happie Vi≈øion of God, and eternall Glorie.

A fifth may be, to con≈øider, what it is that thou de≈øire≈øt: Is it not Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe? Woulde≈øt thou not be Content, and Happie? This is the Way. Looke after all tho≈øe, who euer attained vnto high degree of Re≈øt, and Ioy, and ob≈øerue their ≈øteppes; and thou ≈øhalt finde, that they are all gone in this path of outward Tribulation, and Per≈øecution. And ≈øuppo≈øed, that thou coulde≈øt finde another way to Re≈øt, and Ioyes; woulde≈øt thou for≈øake the comfort of ≈øo good companie,
to goe alone, when as by ≈øo doing, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt but depriue thy ≈øelfe of much Ea≈øe and Ioy.

The ≈øeruants of God, who willingly take paines, and readily ≈øuffer per≈øecution for the loue of God; in their ≈øufferings, and per≈øecutions, doe not ≈øuffer, but in outward ≈øhew, view, and ≈øight of the World; hauing in their inward hearts, and ≈øoules, more Ioyes, and Content, then any Penne, or Tongue, is able to expre≈ø≈øe.

God Almightie is more tender ouer his, who will willingly ≈øuffer per≈øecution for his loue, then euer was the mo≈øt affectioned Mother in the World ouer her onely Child: that giue but thy
con≈øent, free will, and re≈øignation of minde, readily, by Gods grace, to ≈øuffer what≈øoeuer per≈øecution, or tribulation, it ≈øhall plea≈øe his Diuine Maie≈øtie to permit to fall vpon thee, & willingly march on, in that way to Re≈øt, by which he will conduct thee: and ≈øuffer paines of torment thou neuer ≈øhalt; but be ≈øo full of Ioy, in the greate≈øt ≈øeeming paines, that if they were ≈øen≈øible to others, as they will be to thy ≈øelfe, thy ≈øuffering would conuert not one, but all the World. And if thou wilt beleeue the Te≈øtimonies of all pious Men, in this Age, and in all Ages pa≈øt; thou ≈øhalt finde it mo≈øt true, by their Te≈øtimonies, and Experiences, that either
all Content and Ioyes, which are to be found in this life, or the mo≈øt part, are to be found in ≈øuffering and enduring outward paines, labours, and per≈øecutions, for the loue of God: ≈øuch are the Promi≈øes of God, as wee haue ≈øaid immediately before; and God Almightie is iu≈øt and faithfull in all his Promi≈øes, if there be no defect on thy behalfe. So the Prophet Dauid affirmeth, ≈øaying, According P≈ø. 93. 19. to the multitude of my ≈øorrowes in my heart, thy con≈øolations haue made my ≈øoule ioyfull.

Againe, Thou ha≈øt proued vs, O Lord, by fire; thou ha≈øt P≈ø. 65. 9. tryed vs, as Siluer is tryed; thou ha≈øt brought vs vnto a Snare; thou ha≈øt laid Tribulations on our backes; thou ha≈øt
≈øet men vpon our heads; we haue pa≈ø≈øed through fire, and water, and thou ha≈øt brought vs out into refre≈øhing. So Saint Paul often affirmeth, ≈øaying, As the 2. Cor. 1. 5. Pa≈ø≈øions of Chri≈øt abound in vs, ≈øo al≈øo by Chri≈øt doth our comfort abound. Againe, We make 2. Cor. 8. 2. it knowne vnto you, Brethren, the grace of God, that is giuen in the Church of Macedonia, that in much experience of Tribulation, they had abundance of Ioy. Againe, to the Corinthians, liuing in per≈øecution, and tribulation, hee writeth, ≈øaying, Our hope is firme for you, 2. Cor. 1. 7. knowing, that as you are partakers of the Pa≈ø≈øion, ≈øo ≈øhall you be of the Con≈øolation al≈øo: And further affirmeth, ≈øaying, All Di≈øcipline, for the pre≈øent, truly Heb. 12. 11. ≈øeemeth not to be of Ioy, but
of Sorrow: but after, it will render vnto them that are exerci≈øed in it, mo≈øt peaceable fruit of Iu≈øtice. So S. Peter witne≈ø≈øeth, ≈øaying, My deare≈øt, communicating
‚Ä¢ . Pet. 4. 12. with the Pa≈ø≈øions of Chri≈øt, be glad, that in the reuelation al≈øo of his glorie, you may be glad, reioycing. If you be reuiled in the Name of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, you ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed, becau≈øe that which is of the honour, glorie, and vertue of God, and the Spirit, which is his, ≈øhall re≈øt vpon you: The holy Gho≈øt will re≈øt vpon you with his gifts, and fruites; from who≈øe communication, proceedeth all our Content and Happine≈ø≈øe, as wee will ≈øhew in his place. So Saint Paul concludeth, That all men, without exception, ≈øhall find Content by Per≈øecution,
≈øaying, All that will liue godly 1. Tim. 3. 12. in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, ≈øhall ≈øuffer Per≈øecution.

Whereby thou ≈øee≈øt, that if either the light of Rea≈øon, or Grace, may preuaile with thee, thou ha≈øt no cau≈øe to hate, or wi≈øh euill vnto the per≈øons of the Pur≈øuinants, or ≈øeuere≈øt Per≈øecutors; but to hate and dete≈øt their ≈øinne, impietie, and wickedne≈ø≈øe, and loue, cheri≈øh, and doe all the ≈øeruiceable offices thou can≈øt, vnto their per≈øons: ≈øince that by patiently enduring the euils and wickedne≈ø≈øe they practi≈øe vpon thee, God Almightie hath di≈øpo≈øed, to conduct thee to more temporall, and eternall Re≈øt, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe,
then euer otherwi≈øe thou coulde≈øt haue expected to haue receiued.

Which con≈øidered, thou oughte≈øt to haue great compa≈ø≈øion vpon tho≈øe poore, mi≈øerable, and wretched people, which ≈øerue for nothing el≈øe, but, by God Almighties permi≈ø≈øion, to conduct thee to Happine≈ø≈øe; after, to de≈øcend them≈øelues into eternall Torments: and out of compa≈ø≈øion, to pray much for them, if peraduenture, God Almightie will haue mercie on them al≈øo; that they may ≈øee their errors, and come to loue God Almighty with their whole hearts, and their neighbours as them≈øelues, and ≈øaue their ≈øoules; that tho≈øe whom thou ha≈øt had as per≈øecutors
vpon Earth, thou maye≈øt haue as companions of Glorie in Heauen; which God Almightie graunt vs: and to that end I ≈øet downe the≈øe Acts following.

div.head: Acts of Charitie, or Loue toward our Neighbour.
div.p:
O King of Kings, in who≈øe hands are the hearts of all Kings; for thy tender mercies, I be≈øeech thee, graunt, that my King, Queene, and Prince, may ≈øo liue and ≈øerue thee vpon Earth, that after death they may be found in the great Multitude, which no Apoc. 7. 9. man could number, of all Nations, Tribes, and Peoples, and Tongues, which are to be ≈øigned with thy Marke, and to be conducted Apoc. 7. 17
to the Fountaine of liuing Waters.

O Lord of infinite Maie≈øtie, let the petition of thy ≈øeruant be accepted in thy ≈øight, and graunt, that this my King, and his Seed, may be numbred among≈øt that Seed, to which thou promi≈øed, I will put his Seed for euer, and P≈ø. 88. 30. his Throne as the dayes of Heauen.

Thou art faithfull, deare Lord, and iu≈øt, and right, without any iniquitie, and ha≈øt promi≈øed, That who≈øoeuer ≈øhall 1. King. 2. 30. glorifie thee, thou wilt glorifie him, and they that contemne thee, ≈øhalbe ba≈øe. Graunt, deare Lord, that this my King, Queene, and Prince, may ≈øo glorifie thee in all their actions and deeds, that thou maye≈øt glorifie
them vpon Earth, and in Heauen eternally.

Mo≈øt mercifull Lord, I be≈øeech thy infinite Goodne≈ø≈øe ≈øo to illuminate the hearts of all ≈øinners, that they may come to doe heartie penance for their ≈øinnes, and ≈øeeke to loue thee with all their hearts.

Graunt, deare Lord, for the Pa≈ø≈øion of thy onely Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that all tho≈øe Schi≈ømatikes and Heretikes, who in effect defend, that thou ha≈øt fayled, in maintaining thy Oath and Promi≈øes to Abraham, the Prophets, and Patriarkes, for many hundred yeares; may ≈øee their errors, and returne vnto our Catholike Church; in which are abundantly fulfilled all thy Oathes and Promi≈øes.
Forgiue, ≈øweet Sauiour, all tho≈øe who per≈øecute me; and graunt, that they may come ≈øo to loue thee in this life, that after death, they may for euer enioy thee in Heauen.

I be≈øeech thee, my Lord, by the bowels of thy infinite mercie, that all ≈øuch as ≈øeeke after Ambition, and earthly Dignities, may turne all their Affections vpon thee, who art their onely true felicitie.
Graunt, deare Lord, that I may rather die, then not heartily loue and pray for my ≈øeuere≈øt Per≈øecutors.

Deare Lord, for thy infinite mercies, I be≈øeech thee, ≈øo to illuminate the hearts of all the Prote≈øtant Engli≈øh Clergie, our deare Countreymen; that they may ≈øee thy Oathes and
Promi≈øes fulfilled in our Catholike Church, and returne vnto it with all their hearts.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII. Of the wretchedne≈ø≈øe and mi≈øeries into which tho≈øe fall, who liue in breach of the Commandements of God, and doe beleeue, that it is not nece≈ø≈øarie, or impo≈ø≈øible, to keepe them.
div.p:
HAuing ≈øhewed thee, (deare Reader) that it is not po≈ø≈øible for thee euer to be happie, or find any true Content, Ea≈øe, or Re≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe thou keepe the Commaundements of God; and al≈øo hauing ≈øet downe vnto thee the
meanes, by which thou maye≈øt ea≈øily keepe them: Now it re≈øteth, to ≈øet downe the mi≈øeries, and wretchedne≈ø≈øe, into which tho≈øe fall, who liue in breach of them, and e≈øteeme it a thing impo≈ø≈øible for to keepe them; that either for the loue of thine owne good, and content, or el≈øe for feare of thy falling into mi≈øeries & torments, thou maye≈øt be woon to keepe them zealou≈øly, & ≈øo be happy; which is that I heartily wi≈øh vnto thee.

Fir≈øt, tho≈øe who doe not loue God with all their hearts, and keepe his Commaundements, are ≈øpirituall Idolaters, and doe liue in ≈øpirituall Idolatrie. For our Sauiour explicating of the fir≈øt Commaundement, which is made again≈øt
Idolatrie, and the hauing of Exod. 20. 1. ≈øtrange Gods, ≈øayth, Thou ≈øhalt Mat. 22. 37. loue the Lord thy God with thy whole heart, and with thy whole ≈øoule, and with thy whole mind: This is the greate≈øt, and the fir≈øt Commandement, ≈øayth our Sauiour. So, if thou wilt beleeue our Sauiour him≈øelfe, thou mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe, that tho≈øe, who doe not loue God with their whole hearts, and keepe his Commandements, are Idolaters. And the part of Idolaters Apoc. 21. 8. (≈øaith S. Iohn) ≈øhalbe in the Poole burning with fire and Brim≈øtone.

An Idoll, of it ≈øelfe, is not 1. Cor. 10. 19. any thing (as witne≈ø≈øeth Saint Iohn) but the loue & affection which any one beareth to any creature, imagination, or conceit, more then to God, contrarie to the fir≈øt CoÃÑmandement;
whereupon, couetous men are called Idolaters, becau≈øe that Col. 3. 5. they loue Gold and Riches more then God; and la≈øciuious Men, or Gluttons, are ≈øaid Phil. 3. 19. to make their bellies their God: And according to this, our Sauiour ≈øayth, You cannot Mat. 6. 24. ≈øerue God and Mammon. God will haue all thy heart, and loue, or none. Whereupon S. Iohn ≈øayth, Euery one that In his 2. Epi≈øt. Ver. 9. reuolteth, and per≈øi≈øteth not in the Doctrine of Chri≈øt, hath not God, that is, hath no true God, but is an Idolater. Againe, He that ≈øaith he knoweth God, and keepeth not his Commandements, is a lyar.

Whereupon it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe, that how≈øoeuer the≈øe, who thinke it impo≈ø≈øible to keepe the Commaundements
of God, ≈øeeme to adore, laud, and prai≈øe God, and haue the Lord, the God, alwaies in their mouths, & ≈øing Geneua P≈øalms in their Congregations; yet they doe neither ≈øerue their God, nor acknowledge him in their words or ≈øong: but commit ≈øpirituall Idolatrie; apprehending vnder the≈øe termes, the Lord, the God, &c. ≈øuch a God as they haue feigned, and not ≈øuch a God as he is indeed. All Heathen and Cicero de Leg. li. 1. Pagan people that euer were, haue acknowledged a God, and haue ≈øung ≈øongs in prai≈øe; but they did not acknowledge him to be as he is, but as they feigned him to be; as tho≈øe doe, who affirme, that they are a≈ø≈øured to be ≈øaued, without keeping the Commandements
of God; confe≈ø≈øe, that there is a God, a Trinitie, &c. but doe not confe≈ø≈øe him to be ≈øuch a God as he is; that is, a God, who cur≈øeth all the≈øe who decline from his Commandements, P≈øal. 118. according to his Mat. 25. word; but ≈øuch a God, & Trinitie, as they haue feygned; that is to ≈øay, a God which will admit and receiue into Heauen filthie ≈øoules, ≈øtained with Pride, Idolatrie, Fornication, Couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, &c. when there is no ≈øuch God, but onely in their imaginations; as witne≈ø≈øeth Saint Paul, ≈øaying, Doe not erre, neither
‚Ä¢ . Cor. 6. Fornicators, nor ≈øeruers of Idols, nor Adulterers, nor the Effeminate, nor the Lyers with mankinde, nor Theeues, nor the Couetous, nor Drunkards, nor
Raylers, nor Extortioners, ≈øhall inherit the Kingdome of God: For he that hath done iniurie, ≈øhal Col. 3. 25. receiue that which he hath done vniu≈øtly, and there is no acception of Per≈øons with God. There ≈øhall Apoc. 22. not enter into Heauen (≈øaith S. Iohn) any vncleane thing, or that doth abhomination, or maketh a lye. Whereby is manife≈øt, that all tho≈øe who do liue in the breach of the Commandements of God, & do beleeue, that either it is not nece≈ø≈øary, or el≈øe, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to keepe them, are ≈øpirituall Idolaters, and doe adore and ≈øerue ≈øtrange Gods in their ≈øoules and ≈øpirits, contrary to the fir≈øt Commandement; as it is al≈øo manife≈øt to experience: for aske of any one of the≈øe Mini≈øters, if when he Praieth,
or Preacheth, and ≈øaith, The Lord, The God, hee doe not meane the Lord, the God, that ≈øent him to Preach, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to keepe the Commandements of God; and he will ≈øay, Yes: and yet there is no ≈øuch God, but in there imaginations, as we haue proued before. Againe, aske of the≈øe Mini≈øters, if they doe not adore as God, the Lord, the God, who ≈øent them to Preach this, and the like doctrine; and they will ≈øay, Yes: Moreouer, aske of their Di≈øciples and followers, if they doe not beleeue in the God, who ≈øent the≈øe Mini≈øters to Preach Iu≈øtificatioÃÑ by Faith only, without keeping the Commandements; and they will ≈øay, Yes: and yet if thou wilt beleeue
the liuing God, there is no ≈øuch God, but in their imaginations, as we haue ≈øhewed in the former Chapters. Whereby is manife≈øt, that all tho≈øe who liue in the breach of the Commandements of God, and do beleeue, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary, or impo≈ø≈øible to keepe them, are Idolaters, and haue made to them≈øelues ≈øtrange Gods, Gods who will ≈øaue, and make happie by Faith in them, or beleefe in them onely, without keeping their Commandements, or louing them with all their hearts: Strange Gods, that are ≈øo black and vgly, that it is impo≈ø≈øible for men to loue them with all their hearts.

Secondly, they are ≈øonnes of the Deuill, as witne≈ø≈øeth
our Sauiour, ≈øaying, You are Io. 8. 44. of your Father the Diuell, and the de≈øires of your Father you will doe, that is, breake the Commandements; as our Sauiour te≈øtifieth, ≈øaying, He was a man-killer from the beginning, Io. 44. and he ≈øtood not in veritie. And the Law of God is P≈ø. 118. 242. veritie. So our Lord ≈øaith of Iudas, that hee was a Diuell; Haue I not cho≈øen you twelue, Io. 6. 71. and one of you is a Diuell, and he meant Iudas: who by liuing in the breach of the Commandements of God, became a Diuell. And this is ≈øufficient for to ≈øhew vnto thee, deare Reader, the mi≈øerable e≈øtate of the≈øe, who liue and die in the breach of the Commandements of God; that if the loue of thy owne good and content doe not moue thee to keepe them; yet, the feare of mi≈øerie, and torments, may winne thee to ob≈øerue them, that thou maie≈øt by one meanes, or other, attaine vnto the Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, which I heartely wi≈øh vnto thee.

div.head: CHAP. XV. That the Happie, Elect, and Iu≈øt, and all tho≈øe who ≈øhall be ≈øaued, ≈øhall keepe the Law, loue God with their whole hearts, and their Neighbours as them≈øelues.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, it is an horror to Nature, that any man ≈øhould be truely Happy, or Content, who keepeth not the whole Law, or Commandements of God: as, that a Fornicator, Adulterer, Drunkard, Man-killer, V≈øurer, Extortioner, Periured per≈øon, or Hater of God, ≈øhould be receiued into Heauen, or liue with any Content vpoÃÑ earth: for, becau≈øe we ≈øee, that ≈øuch as are guiltie of the≈øe
crimes, and publikely profe≈ø≈øe in print, that they cannot loue God with all their hearts, or liue cha≈øt according to the Law, are not content to be ≈øtiled, or called, haters of God, Adulterers, or Fornicators; becau≈øe of the repugnance, which Nature hath again≈øt the guilt of ≈øinne, and breach of the Commandements of God: which repugnance, forceth them to e≈øteeme the very ≈øtile, of being ≈øo called, as an infamous thing, and badge of vnhappine≈ø≈øe.

And if the onely ≈øtyling of men, with the≈øe names, of fornicators, and haters of God, which is but an extrin≈øecall denomination; bee ≈øo di≈øgu≈øtfull, that no man, though guiltie of the crime, for the good opinion, fame, and e≈øtimation, he de≈øireth to haue before men, will be content to take them for his name, and be generally counted a fornicator, or hater of God: how much more will the vgly guilt and crime of ≈øinne it ≈øelfe, be di≈øgu≈øtfull, before

Whereby it is manife≈øt to rea≈øon, that no man, liuing with the guilt, or ≈øtaine, of the breach of any one Commandement in his ≈øoule, can euer bee Content, or Happy, in this life, or in the other: but that the Happy, Iu≈øt, and Elect, ≈øhall keepe the Commandements of God, loue him with all their hearts, and their Neighbours as them≈øelues.

Ier. 31. Heb. 10. giue my Law in their bowels, and in their heares I wil write it, &c. and ≈øo concludeth his prayer, ≈øaying; I will, that the loue Io. 17. 26. wherewith thou ha≈øt loued mee, may be in them, and I in them.
Whereby is manife≈øt, that the Elect, and all tho≈øe who ≈øhall be ≈øaued, ≈øhall keepe the Law, loue God Almightie with their whole hearts, and their Neighbours as them≈øelues.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. What it is to be content and happie, and how Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, con≈øi≈øteth in louing God Almightie with all our hearts, and our Neighbour, for Gods ≈øake, as our ≈øelues.
div.p:
WE ≈øee by experience, that then euery one is well plea≈øed, when he hath that which he loueth, and loueth that which he ought. Of all the affections in the ≈øoule, Loue is the ≈øtronge≈øt; in≈øomuch, as Loue is ≈øaid to be Cant. 8. as ≈øtrong as Death; and Iealou≈øie, or feare, to lo≈øe that which wee loue, is ≈øaid to be as hard as Hell: euery
one beeing ≈øo loth to part from that which he loueth, that of all paines it is the greate≈øt. So that in Loues motion, are ≈øatisfied and filled all the other affections of our ≈øoules: for who is delighted, but in that which he loueth? or who hateth, flyeth, or is ≈øorrowfull, but for ≈øome euill, which may ≈øeparate him from the good he loueth? or who hopeth, or de≈øpaireth, but in the difficultie he findeth in obtaining the good he loueth? or who feareth, dareth, or is angrie, but at the euill which oppo≈øeth it ≈øelfe to the good he de≈øireth? ≈øo that in Loues motions are complete all our happine≈ø≈øe, and affections. If a man ≈øhall Cant. 8. giue all the ≈øub≈øtance of his hou≈øe
for loue, as nothing he will di≈øpi≈øe it. He is violently carryed, whom loue driueth; and he was neuer poore, or di≈øcontent, that found what he de≈øired: and all ≈øo earne≈øtly de≈øire that which they loue, as aske of any one who≈øoeuer, what is that which hath greate≈øt force with him? and he will an≈øwere, his loue, and plea≈øure: Yet all the plea≈øures which a man can take, are in ≈øome ≈øpeciall, good, that is, hone≈øt, profitable, and delightfull; for he that de≈øireth that which is di≈øhone≈øt, is a≈øhamed; he that de≈øireth that which is not profitable, loo≈øeth; and he that de≈øireth that which proueth not delightfull, repenteth; and he that obtaineth that which is
hone≈øt, and yet hath not in it all hone≈øtie, is defectiue; and hee that obtaineth that which is profitable, yet hath not all the profit that he is capable of to receiue, is ≈øtill poore; and hee that hath that which delighteth him, and yet not all delights, wanteth: whereby we gather, that the good which may giue vs complete content, may be of all things hone≈øt, the mo≈øt hone≈øt; of all things profitable, the mo≈øt profitable; and of all things delightfull, the mo≈øt plea≈øing: and yet one it mu≈øt needes be; for if in one thing I ≈øhould loue hone≈øtie, and in another, profit, I ≈øhould be diuided; and diui≈øion weakeneth loue, breaketh affection,
and bringeth affliction. Againe, this one thing mu≈øt be euery where, and in all places pre≈øent vnto me; otherwi≈øe I could not alwaies, and in all places, be pre≈øent vnto it, and happie.

Whereupon I an≈øwere, that according to the light of naturall rea≈øon, Content doth not only con≈øi≈øt in Loue, but in louing one thing, which hath in it, all hone≈øtie, profite, and plea≈øure, and all other things for it; and that one thing is to be euery where, and in all places, which is, God Almightie, call it what you will, This is my God, and Exod. 15. 2. I will glorifie him; the God of my Fathers, and I will exalt him; who is mo≈øt high,
mo≈øt ≈øweet, mo≈øt potent, mo≈øt mercifull, mo≈øt iu≈øt, mo≈øt ≈øecret, mo≈øt pre≈øent, mo≈øt ≈øtrong, mo≈øt incomprehen≈øible, mo≈øt wi≈øe, mo≈øt beautifull, mo≈øt happie; of infinite Hone≈øtie, Wi≈øedome, Beautie, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe: who giueth all that any hath, and yet is neuer the poorer; and accepteth what is giuen him, and yet is neuer the richer: in louing him, and all other things for him, con≈øi≈øteth all our Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe.

O deceiued ≈øonnes of Men! you ≈øeeke Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, and Content in the Earth, and it is in your inward ≈øoules: turne, ≈øinners, into your hearts, and there you ≈øhall finde it; it is
within you, and you are without your ≈øelues; it is pre≈øent to you, and you are ab≈øent to it; it is before your faces, and you put your ≈øelues vpon your backs; you ≈øeeke for it without, and it is within your hearts: as witne≈ø≈øeth the Prophet Dauid, P≈ø. 72. ≈øaying, God of my heart, and God my portion for euer; and in all places, more pre≈øent to you, then you are to your ≈øelues: For in him Act. 17. 28. wee liue, and moue, and bee.

This is thy Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, The Mat. 6. 33. kingdome of Heauen, the iu≈øtice of our Lord, to loue thy God Mat. ‚Ä¢ 2 37. from thy whole heart, and with thy whole ≈øoule‚ñ™ with thy whole minde, and thy Neighbour as
thy ≈øelfe. On the≈øe two Commaundements Mat. 22. 38. (as our Lord ≈øaith) doe depend the whole Law & the Prophets; this is the Mirth, Ioy, Peace, and Content, which is not giuen to the wicked, but to ≈øuch as ≈øerue God gratis, who≈øe Ioy and Content he is.

This is happie life, O Lord, to Au. li. Con. 10. ca. 22. reioice in thee, of thee, for thee; this is it, and other there is none. O all ye that thir≈øt, come to the I≈øa. 55. waters, and you that haue no ≈øiluer, make ha≈øt, buy and eate, come buy without ≈øiluer, or without any exchange, wine, and milke: why be≈øtow you ≈øiluer, & not for bread, Boetius li. 2. Pro. 4. and your labour, and not for ≈øatietie. O mortall men! why ≈øeeke you for your happine≈ø≈øe abroad, which is placed within your ≈øelues? Hearing, heare you me, I≈øa. 55.
and eate that which is good, and your ≈øoules ≈øhall bee delighted with fatne≈ø≈øe; with content vpon Earth, and happine≈ø≈øe for all eternitie in Heauen. Ble≈ø≈øed is the man who≈øe will P≈ø. 1. is in the Law of our Lord, and in his Law ≈øhall meditate day and night; all things what≈øoeuer he ≈øhall doe, ≈øhall pro≈øper. To them that loue God, all Rom. 8. 28. things cooperate vnto good, to ≈øuch as according to purpo≈øe, are called to bee Saints. Loue thou God Almightie with thy whole heart, and thy Neighbour for Gods ≈øake, as thy ≈øelfe, and all things will be plea≈øing, all things delightfull, all things profitable, all things that to thee, which thou woulde≈øt de≈øire, or wi≈øh in Charitie,
or the loue of God, and our Neighbour, is ≈øatisfied, and filled all our affections. Charitie Col. 3. 14. is the bond of perfection, which comprehendeth in it all other vertues. Charitie 1. Cor. 13. 4. is patient, is benigne; Charitie enuieth not, dealeth not peruer≈øly; is not puffed vp, is not ambitious‚ñ™ ≈øeeketh not her owne, is not prouoked to anger, thinketh no euill, reioiceth not vpon iniquitie; but reioiceth with the truth, ≈øuffereth all things, beleeueth all things. Charitie 1. Tim. 4. 8. neuer falleth away, is profitable to all things, hauing promi≈øe of the life that now is, and of that to come.

Whereupon, Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øaith, The Apo≈øtle Paul, Tract. 8. in Ioan. initio. when again≈øt the workes of the fle≈øh hee would commend the
fruits of the ≈øpirit, put Charitie as head, ≈øaying, the fruits of the ≈øpirit is Charitie, and then putteth the re≈øt in order, as ri≈øing from this head, and bound to it; which are, Ioy, Peace, Longanimitie, Benignitie, Goodne≈ø≈øe, Faith, Mildne≈ø≈øe, Continence, Cha≈øtitie. Which the Saint ≈øhewing to be true, by experience, addeth, For who doth well reioice, but he who loueth ≈øome good wherein he may reioice? who hath any true friend≈øhip or peace with any, but with him whom he ≈øincerely loueth? who deth long per≈øeuere in doing good workes, vnle≈ø≈øe he be hot in louing? who is benigne, but he that loueth tho≈øe whom hee may helpe? who is good, vnle≈ø≈øe hee bee made by louing? who
is faithfull to ≈øaluation, but by that faith which worketh by loue? who is courageou≈øly meeke, but whom loue doth moderate? who doth ab≈øtaine from that which may make him filthie, but hee that loueth ≈øomething, by which hee may be hone≈øted? Worthily therefore doth our good Ma≈øter ≈øo often commend Loue, as though it were onely to be commended; without the which, other goods can nothing profite vs, and which cannot bee had without other goods, wherewith a man is to bee made good: ≈øo Saint Augu≈øtine.

And according to the≈øe words of Saint Augu≈øtine, are the words of Saint Paul, ≈øaying, Circumci≈øion is nothing,
and Prepuce is nothing, 1. Cor. 7. 19. but the ob≈øeruation of the Commaundements of God. Againe, In Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, neither Gal. 5. 5. Circumci≈øion auaileth ought, nor Prepuce, but Faith that worketh by Charitie. Againe, The≈ø. 3. 12. Our Lord multiplie you, and make your Charitie abound one towards another, and towards all men, as we al≈øo in you, to confirme your hearts without blame, in holine≈ø≈øe, before God, and our Father, in the comming of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, with all his Saints: Who, when hee ≈øhall come to Iudgement, if wee will beleeue him≈øelfe, ≈øhall condemne to euerla≈øting paines all tho≈øe who wanted Charitie towards their Neighbours, and haue broken this
Precept, Thou ≈øhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelfe. Iewes, Gentiles, and Heretikes, who doe not beleeue the Oathes of God, and the Faith planted by our Lord, are alreadie Ioh. 3. 18. iudged, becau≈øe they doe not beleeue in the Name of the onely Sonne of God: And ≈øhall ari≈øe onely to receiue their finall doome, and damnation, with ≈øuch Catholikes as had Faith, but wanted Charitie, To feede Mat. 25. the hungrie, giue drinke to the thir≈øtie, harbour the ≈øtranger, couer the naked, vi≈øit the ≈øicke, &c. The≈øe (for all their faith, if we will beleeue the Iudge him≈øelfe) ≈øhall goe into puni≈øhment euerla≈øting, which was prepared for the Diuell and his Angels: But the Iu≈øt, ≈øuch as feede the hungry, giue drinke
to the thir≈øtie, &c. ≈øhall goe into life euerla≈øting; according to the Prophecies, Our Lord P≈ø. 144. keepeth all that loue him, and he will de≈øtroy all ≈øinners. Whereupon S. Paul ≈øayth, That the 1. Tim. 1. 5. end of the Precept is Charitie, from a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained. From a pure Heart; according to the words of our Lord, Happie are the cleane of Mat. 5. 8. heart, for they ≈øhall ≈øee God: and a good Con≈øcience; according to the words of S. Peter, With mode≈øtie, and feare, 1. Pet. 3. 15. hauing a good Con≈øcience; that in that which they ≈øpeake euill of you, they may be confounded, which calumniate your good conuer≈øation in Chri≈øt: A Faith not fained; not ≈øuch a Faith as Prote≈øtants haue: who
faine, that they are a≈ø≈øured to be ≈øaued, without keeping the Commaundements of God; when neither the Apostles, nor Prophets, make any mention of any ≈øuch thing: but a Faith founded vpon the Doctrine of the Apo≈øtles and Prophets, Ie≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelfe being the Ephe. 2. 20. highe≈øt corner Stone; A Faith, which doth e≈øtabli≈øh the Law; Rom. 3. 31. a Faith conioyned to a good Con≈øcience: according to the words of S. Paul, Hauing Faith 1. Tim. 1. 19. and a good Con≈øcience; which certaine repelling, haue made ≈øhipwracke about the Faith.

Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øpeaking of this definition of Charitie, ≈øayth, Charitie is our fruit; Tract. 8. in Ioan. which the Apo≈øtle defineth, of a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained:
by this we loue one another, by this wee loue God; neyther ≈øhould wee loue one another with true loue, but by louing God: For euery one doth loue his Neighbour as him≈øelfe, if hee loue God; for if hee doe not loue God, hee doth not loue him≈øelfe.

Since all Content and Happine≈ø≈øe con≈øi≈øteth in louing of God, and all other things for God; hee depriueth him≈øelfe of all true good and content, who doth not loue God with all his heart: as in another place, the ≈øaid Saint further confe≈ø≈øeth, ≈øaying; Let vs heare De mo ‚Ä¢ ib. Ecc. Catho. O Chri≈øt, what end (or re≈øt) of goods thou pre≈øcribe≈øt vnto vs, that is without all controuer≈øie, the end, or re≈øt; to which thou commande≈øt vs to encline vnto with all loue.
Thou ≈øaye≈øt, thou ≈øhalt loue the Lord thy God from thy whole Mat. 22. 37. heart, and with thy whole ≈øoule, and with thy whole mind. Thither we are altogether to tend; to that all our Coun≈øels are to be referred; the chiefe≈øt of all good, God is vnto vs. God is to vs the chiefe≈øt good; neither are we to remaine lower, nor yet to ≈øeeke any thing beyond him. The one is dangerous, and the other is nothing. The following of God, is the de≈øire of Happine≈ø≈øe; and the attaining God, Happine≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe: and we follow him, by louing him; and attaine to him, when we are not altogether made that which he is; but adorned with his vertue, and ≈øanctitie, we are neere vnto him, and touch him after a wonderfull and vnder≈øtanding manner.

Againe, For what other thing Aug. de morib. Ecc. Catho. ≈øhould be the chiefe≈øt good of Man, but that, to which to cleaue vnto, maketh mo≈øt happie: and that is onely God; to whom, verily, we cannot cleaue vnto‚ñ™ but by Loue and Charitie. And if Vertue doth lead vs to happie life; I would affirme, Vertue to be nothing el≈øe, but the ca≈øting of all our loue vpon God. And therefore I will not doubt, to define the≈øe foure (Cardinall) Vertues after this manner: That Temperance ≈øhould bee Loue, giuing it ≈øelfe wholly to him that is beloued; Fortitude to be Loue, ea≈øily ≈øuffering or enduring all things for the thing beloued; Iu≈øtice to be Loue, ≈øeruing onely the beloued, and therefore rightly ruling; Prudence to be Loue, wittily ≈øeparating
and di≈øcerning tho≈øe thinges wherewith it is helped, from tho≈øe by whom it is hindered. But we ≈øay, that this loue is not of what thing ≈øoeuer, but of God, that is to ≈øay, of the chiefe≈øt Good, chiefe≈øt Wi≈øedome, chiefe≈øt Concord: Wherefore wee may al≈øo, after this manner, define the≈øe foure (Cardinall) Vertues, and ≈øay, That Temperance is Loue, pre≈øeruing it ≈øelfe whole and vn≈øpotted to God; Fortitude to be Loue, patiently ≈øuffering all things for God; Iu≈øtice to be Loue, onely ≈øeruing God, and for his ≈øake, well gouerning other things which are vnder his charge; Prudence to be Loue, well di≈øcerning the≈øe things wherewithall it is helped into God, from the≈øe by which it may be hindered.

Againe, Charitie is the mo≈øt Aug. de Nat. et gra. ca. 42. ibi. ca. 70. true, the mo≈øt full, and mo≈øt perfect Iu≈øtice; vnperfect Charitie is vnperfect Iu≈øtice, encrea≈øed Charitie is encrea≈øed Iu≈øtice, perfect Charitie is perfect Iu≈øtice: but we vnder≈øtand Charitie from a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained; which then is the mo≈øt perfect that it can be in this life, when for the loue of it, life is de≈øpi≈øed. So Saint Augu≈øtine.

Whereupon the Councell of Trent, Se≈ø≈ø. 6. ca. 7. ≈øaith, Although none can be iu≈øt, but to whom the mercies of the Pa≈ø≈øion of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt are communicated; that yet is done by the iu≈øtification of the wicked, whiles by the merite of his mo≈øt holy Pa≈ø≈øion,
the Charitie of God, by the holy Gho≈øt, is poured into the hearts of them who are iu≈øtified, and doth inhere in them. Whereupon, in Iu≈øtification, with remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, a man doth receiue all the≈øe, infu≈øed together, by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; to whom he is ingraffed by Faith, Hope, and Charitie: For Faith, vnle≈ø≈øe Hope be added vnto it, and Charitie, neither doth perfectly vnite with Chri≈øt, neither doth it make a liuing Member of his Bodie. And according to this, are the words of S. Paul, ≈øaying of Rom. 13. 10. Loue, That it is the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Law; Diuine Loue, or Charitie, comprehendeth in it all other Vertues, fulfilleth the whole Law, or Commandements of God. If there be Rom. 13. any other Commandement, it is
comprehended in this word, Thou ≈øhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelfe: The loue of thy Neighbour worketh no euill. So Saint 1. Ioh. 3 10. Iohn ≈øayth, Euery one that is not iu≈øt (that keepeth not the Commandements) is not of God; and he that loueth not his Brother: becau≈øe this is the Annunciation, which you haue heard, from the beginning, That you loue one another. Againe, Ioh. 13. 35. In this all men ≈øhall know that you are my Di≈øciples, if you haue loue one to another. Whereupon Saint Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, In 1. Ep. Ioa. tract. 5. Therefore Loue onely di≈øcerneth betweene the ≈øonnes of God, and the ≈øonnes of the Diuell: All ≈øigne them≈øelues with the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt; all an≈øwer, Amen; all ≈øing, Alleluia; all are Baptized; all come to
the Church, and build the walls of Churches. The ≈øonnes of God are not di≈øcerned from the ≈øonnes of the Diuell, but by Charitie. Tho≈øe who haue charitie, are borne of God; tho≈øe who haue not charitie, are not borne of God. Haue a great Iudgement, haue a great Di≈øcretion, or haue what thou wilt, if this thou ha≈øt not, the other doe nothing profit thee. Whereupon the Prophet Dauid ≈øaith, Ble≈ø≈øed are P≈ø. 118. 1. the immaculate in the way, who walke in the Law of our Lord; and loue God with all their hearts, and their Neighbours for Gods ≈øake, as them≈øelues: Ble≈ø≈øed are they that ≈øearch his P≈ø. 118. 2. te≈øtimonies, that ≈øeeke after him with all their hearts; for they ≈øhall be happie vpon Earth; and eternally ble≈ø≈øed in Heauen:
according to the words of our Sauiour, ≈øaying, Ble≈ø≈øed Mat. 5. 3. Mat. 19. 29. are the poore in ≈øpirit; ≈øuch as haue left all things for the loue of God: Ble≈ø≈øed are the Mat. 11. 2 ‚Ä¢ . meeke; ≈øuch as for his loue, learne meekene≈ø≈øe of him: Ble≈ø≈øed are they that mourne; for that they haue offended God, and broken his Law: Ble≈ø≈øed are they that hunger and thir≈øt after Iu≈øtice; the keeping of the Law: Ble≈ø≈øed are the mercifull; who feede the Hungrie, giue drinke to the Thir≈øtie, cloathe the Naked, &c. Ble≈ø≈øed are the cleane of heart; ≈øuch as haue Charitie: which S. Paul defineth to be, of a pure Heart, a good Con≈øcience, and Faith not fained. Ble≈ø≈øed are the Peace-makers; ≈øuch as teach men, to loue
their Neighbours as them≈øelues; thereby to take away all Suites, and Controuer≈øies: no man commencing a Suit again≈øt him≈øelfe. Ble≈ø≈øed are they that ≈øuffer per≈øecution for Iu≈øtice; out of their loues to God, defending his Honor, the fulfilling of his Oathes, and ≈øeeking inuiolably to keepe his Commandements.

Whereupon we conclude, that in the louing of God Almightie, with our whole hearts, and with our whole ≈øoules, and with our whole mindes, and our Neighbour (for Gods ≈øake) as our ≈øelues; con≈øi≈øteth all our Ea≈øe, Re≈øt, Repo≈øe, Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe. So God graunt thee (deare Reader) abundance of Charitie towards God and
