div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the temporall Ble≈ø≈øing, and Contentments, which ≈øuch enioy, as loue God with their whole hearts, and their neighbour for Gods ≈øake, as them≈øelues.
div.p:
HAuing e≈øtabli≈øhed our Doctrine, of Content and Happine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øufficiently ≈øhewed, that it con≈øi≈øteth in Charitie, from a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained, which comprehendeth in it, all other vertues; and al≈øo hauing ≈øhewed thee,
how thou maye≈øt become charitable: now it re≈øteth to ≈øet downe, the Ble≈ø≈øings, Repo≈øe, and Happine≈ø≈øe, which we may by Gods grace, attaine vnto, by the practi≈øe of this Doctrine, The loue of God with all our hearts, and our neighbour for Gods ≈øake, as our ≈øelues. And fir≈øt, it is nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øpeake of temporall ble≈ø≈øings, and contentments; and after, of ≈øpirituall, and eternall.

The practi≈øe of this our Doctrine (of louing God with all our hearts, and our neighbours for Gods ≈øake, as our ≈øelues) yeeldeth ≈øuch abundance of temporall Happine≈ø≈øe, and Content, as that it taketh away all the cau≈øes of temporall di≈øcontent, and mi≈øeries,
from among≈øt men, and planteth in their places, all temporall Happine≈ø≈øe, and Contentments: for ≈øuppo≈øed, that this our Doctrine were practi≈øed among≈øt men, and that euerie one would loue God with all his heart, and his neighbour for God, as him≈øelfe; fir≈øt, it would take away all V≈øurie, Theft, Murder, Fornication, Adulterie, Suits in Law, Sects, Controuer≈øies, Rebellions, Con≈øpiracies, Enuie, Hatred, Malice, Emulations, Oppre≈ø≈øions, Contentions, and what≈øoeuer mi≈øerie is in any Kingdome, State, or Commonwealth; and all the euils which are prohibited and forbidden by Lawes. For if we did loue God Almightie with all our hearts, wee
≈øhould be verie ≈øorrie to offend him: As wee ≈øee by experience; euerie one hath great care, not to offend him whom hee loueth. So, if men loued God Almightie with all their hearts; there would bee no ≈øuch ≈øinnes committed, as are ≈øpoken of in the Tenne Commaundements, or in anie other Ciuill, or Common Law: According to the wordes of our Sauiour, ≈øaying; If any loue mee, hee Ioh. 14. 23. will keepe my Word. Againe, Hee that loueth me not, keepeth Io. 14. 24. not my wordes. So, e≈øtabli≈øh the loue of God in the hearts of men; and you take away all Idolatrie, Theft, Fornication, Adulterie, Couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, Extortion,
Iniu≈øtice, Sinne, and Wickedne≈ø≈øe, forbidden by any Law: To the verifying of the vvordes, ≈øpoken by the Prophet I≈øay, ≈øaying; Iu≈øtice ≈øhall be I≈øa. 11. 5. the girdle of his Loynes; and Faith, the girdle of his Reynes: The Wolfe ≈øhall dwell with the Lambe, and the Leopard ≈øhall lye with the Kid: The Calfe, and Lion, and Sheepe, ≈øhall abide together; a little child ≈øhall leade them: The Calfe, and the Beare, ≈øhall feede; their young ones ≈øhall re≈øt together: And the Lion ≈øhall eate Straw, as it were an Oxe: And the Infant, from the Brea≈øt, ≈øhall be delighted vpon the hole of the A≈øpe:
and he that is weyned, ≈øhall thru≈øt his hand into the hole of the Cockatrice. They ≈øhall not hurt, and they ≈øhall not kill in all my holy Mountaine; becau≈øe the Earth is repleni≈øhed with the knowledge of our Lord, the loue of God, and Man: for he that ≈øaith, he knoweth God, and keepeth not his Commaundements, 1. Ioh. 2. 4. is a lyar, and the truth is not in him. Whereby thou ≈øee≈øt, deare Reader, that the practi≈øe of our Doctrine, taketh away all temporall mi≈øeries, and wretchedne≈ø≈øe, from among≈øt men; in≈øomuch, as if that it vvere practi≈øed, there vvould bee no neede of Lawes, nor any v≈øe of any Lawyers.

Againe, ≈øuppo≈øed that euerie one would loue his neighbour, as his ≈øecond ≈øelfe; then, all would relieue the poore, and euerie one would reioyce at others good, and pro≈øperitie, as at his owne; and all ≈øeeke to aduance one, and one, all; and found a perfect Monarchie, in defence inuincible; and in offence, again≈øt the enemies of their common good, alwayes conquerors: euery one faithfully ≈øeconding of his companion, as his ≈øecond ≈øelfe, they would remaine inuincible; and euerie one louing his neighbour as him≈øelfe, euerie one would willingly ≈øupply, to his power, his neighbours wants; and by this
meanes they would all liue in happie and quiet temporall Content, like perfect friends, confirmed in ≈øociable amitie; according to the Prophecies: Thy People all I≈øa. 60. 21. iu≈øt, for euer ≈øhall inherite the Land; the Budde of my planting, the worke of my hand to glorie: The lea≈øt ≈øhall be into a thou≈øand; and the little one, into a mo≈øt ≈øtrong Nation: the Lord, in the time thereof, will ≈øuddainely doe it. Againe, I will make thy vi≈øitation, I≈øa. 60. 18. Peace, and thy Ouer≈øeers, Iu≈øtice; Iniquitie ≈øhall no more be heard in thy Land, Wa≈øte, and De≈øtruction, in thy Borders; and Saluation ≈øhall occupie thy Walls, and Prai≈øe, thy Gates.

And this wee ≈øee fulfilled, in the Chri≈øtians of the Primitiue Church: Of whom it is ≈øaid; The multitude Act. 4. 32. of Beleeuers had one Heart, and one Soule; neyther did any ≈øay, that ought was his owne, of tho≈øe thinges which hee po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed: And is, euen vntill this day, fulfilled in all poore reformed Religious Orders, dilated ouer the World; who neuer ≈øtand in need to v≈øe Suites, or Lawyers. And it is al≈øo fulfilled in all Countreyes, more or le≈ø≈øe, accordingly, as they are Chri≈øtians Catholike, or ≈øtayned with ≈øpots of Here≈øie.

All the temporall Ble≈ø≈øings of Monarchies, Kingdomes, and States, are founded
vpon the keeping of the Commaundements of God; according to that Pact, or Couenant, which Moy≈øes made with the people of I≈ørael, which now wee Chri≈øtians are, ≈øaying: If thou wilt heare Deut. 28. the voice of our Lord thy God, that thou doe and keepe all his Commandements, which I commaund thee this day, our Lord thy God will make thee higher then all Nations that be on the Earth, and all tho≈øe Ble≈ø≈øings ≈øhall come vpon thee, and ouertake thee; yet ≈øo, if thou heare his Precepts. Ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhalt thou be in the Citie, and ble≈ø≈øed in the Field, ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhall be the fruit of thy Wombe, and the fruit of thy Ground, and the fruit of thy Cattell, the troopes of thy Heards, and the foulds
of thy Sheepe, &c. Our Lord will rai≈øe thee vp vnto him≈øelfe, to be a holy People, as he ≈øware to thee, if thou keepe the Commaundements of our Lord thy God, and walke in his wayes. And all the people of the Earth ≈øhall ≈øee, that the Name of our Lord is inuocated vpon thee, and they ≈øhall feare thee, &c. And our Lord will make thee the Head, and not the Tayle, and thou ≈øhalt be alwayes aboue, and not vnder; yet ≈øo, if thou wilt heare the Commandements of our Lord thy God, which I commaunded thee this day, and keepe and doe them, &c.

Which wee ≈øee to haue beene fulfilled, in all Ages, among≈øt Chri≈øtian People, Emperours, Kings, Empires, Kingdomes, and States: in≈øomuch,
as that the≈øe were alwayes the mo≈øt renowmed, happie, ble≈ø≈øed, and fortunate Kingdomes, who mo≈øt followed the Doctrine of the Catholike Church, and attended to the keeping of the Commaundements of God. As of Con≈øtantine the Great, Saint Augu≈øtine writeth, ≈øaying: Ciuit. Dei, li. 5. ca. 6. Constantine the Emperour, not ≈øuppliant to Deuils, but wor≈øhipping the true God, receiued ≈øo many gifts and ble≈ø≈øings from God, as none dur≈øt pre≈øume to wi≈øh: This one Augu≈øtus, held, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and defended the whole Romane Empire. In admini≈øtrating of Warre, he was iu≈øt, and victorious; in vanqui≈øhing, and repre≈ø≈øing Tyrants, wonderfull pro≈øperous: being of great yeares, he died, of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe,
and old age; his ≈øonnes, Emperours, to ≈øucceed him.

Of Theodo≈øius the elder, S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, That hee De Ciuit. Dei li. 5. ca. 26. had wonderfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in all his affaires, becau≈øe hee was a pious Catholike Emperour; that in the Battailes he fought with his Enemies, their owne Weapons, Darts, and Arrowes, were turned vpon them≈øelues; God Almightie fighting for him.

Of Honorius, a mo≈øt Catholike Emperour, S. Augu≈øtine De Ciuit. Dei li. 5. ca. 28. writeth, That God did ≈øo fight for him, as in one Battaile he ≈ølew, of the Gothes, aboue a hundreth thou≈øand, and tooke their King, and his ≈øonne, pri≈øoners; and not ≈øo much as one of his Armie killed, or wounded.

Of Theodo≈øius the yonger, a verie pious Emperor, writeth Socrates, That making Lib. 7. hi≈øt. ca. 18. his prayers to God, while his Armie skirmi≈øhed with the Sarazens, a hundred thou≈øand of them were driuen, by Angels, into the Riuer Euphrates, and there peri≈øhed.
The ≈øame pro≈øperitie followed Iu≈øtine the elder, and Hieraclius, while≈øt they were Catholike Emperors; but after they became Heretikes, they neuer did any thing pro≈øperou≈øly.

And to let pa≈ø≈øe Charles the Great, Charles the fift, and manie more Catholike Chri≈øtian Kings, and Emperors; who attained to pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, in their affaires, a≈øwell in warre, as in
peace, by being pious Catholike Princes, carefully ≈øeeking to keepe the Commaundements of God: And to ≈øpeake of the Kings and Princes of this I≈øland.

In S. Au≈øtines time, there were ≈øeuen Kings heere in England: and the re≈øt extingui≈øhed, the Crowne remained, together with the Monarchie, in the Line of the We≈øt Saxons; who were, of all the re≈øt, mo≈øt Catholike, and pious defendors of the keeping of the Commaundedements of God.

And if wee looke yet further into the e≈øtate of this Monarchie of England; wee ≈øhall finde it mo≈øt true, that the mo≈øt flouri≈øhing times, that euer England ≈øaw, was
when it mo≈øt zealou≈øly profe≈ø≈øed Catholike Religion, and piou≈øly labored to keepe the Commandements of God: as in the reigne of Egbert; who fir≈øt reduced England into a Monarchie, in the time of Alfred his ≈øonne; Edward the fir≈øt, and Athel≈øtan, his ≈øonne; Edmund, Edred, Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor; Henrie the fir≈øt, fourth, and fifth; to the verifying of the Promi≈øes and Prophe≈øies, ≈øaying: I would thou hadde≈øt attended to I≈øa. 48. 18. my Commandements; thy Peace had beene as a floud, and thy Iu≈øtice as the waues of the Sea: And thy Seede had beene as the Sand, and the Stocke of thy Wombe, as the grauell ≈øtones thereof: his name had not peri≈øhed, neither had it beene de≈øtroyed
before my face. Againe, Who≈øoeuer 1. King. 3. 30. wil glorifie me, I wil glorifie him: and they that contemne me, ≈øhalbe ba≈øe.

Whereupon the Prophet Dauid ≈øaith; Tribulation and P≈øa. 118. 143. Di≈øtre≈ø≈øe haue found me: Thy Commaundements are my meditation: Thy te≈øtimonies are equitie for euer: giue me vnder≈øtanding, and I ≈øhall liue; by keeping them: enioying the Ble≈ø≈øings and Promi≈øes of God; comfort, and helpe in all his tribulations and nece≈ø≈øities. Ble≈ø≈øed are all that feare P≈ø. 127. 1. our Lord, that walk in his wayes; Becau≈øe thou ≈øhalt eate the labor of thy hands: Ble≈ø≈øed art thou, and it ≈øhalbe wel with thee; in this life, and in all eternitie: which God of his goodne≈ø≈øe graunt thee, Reader.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the fir≈øt ≈øpirituall Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, which ≈øuch enioy, as loue God with all their hearts, and keepe his Commaundements; which is Beautie ≈øpirituall.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt ≈øpirituall Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, vvhich God Almightie be≈øtoweth vpon ≈øuch as loue him, is remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes, clean≈øing and wa≈øhing of their ≈øoules with the water of life, and decking and adorning them with ≈øpirituall Beautie: Let the impious for≈øake his way, and the vniu≈øt I≈øa. 55. 7. man his cogitations, and returne to our Lord, and he will haue
mercie vpon him; and to our God, becau≈øe he is bountifull to forgiue. So great are the mercies of God Almightie, that at what time ≈øoeuer a ≈øinner ≈øhall de≈øi≈øt from violating the Commaundements of God, and returne to loue him with his whole heart, hee will haue mercie on him, and ob≈øerue with him, the faithfull mercies, which hee promi≈øed to Abraham and his Seed, ≈øaying, Who≈øoeuer ≈øhall Eze. 11. 32. 34. 37. depart from his wicked wayes, and turne vnto me, I will receiue him into the Couenant; which hee made with Abraham, Dauid, and the Patriarkes, and their Seed for euer. When Deut. 30. 1. thou ≈øhalt be turned (≈øayth Moy≈øes) with repentance of thy heart, and ≈øhall returne to our
Lord, and obey his Commaundements in all thy heart; our Deut. 30. 9. Lord will turne to reioyce vpon thee, in all riches, as he reioyced in thy Fathers; yet ≈øo, if thou heare the voice of the Lord thy God; and keepe his Precepts.

For thus ≈øayth our Lord; Di≈ø≈øolue the bands of Impietie, I≈øa. 58. 6. loo≈øe the bands that ouer-load; di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them free that are broken, and breake in ≈øunder euerie burden. (Depart from ≈øinne, and doe works of Charitie.) Breake thy Bread to the hungrie, and the needie, and harbourle≈ø≈øe, bring into thy hou≈øe; when thou ≈øhalt ≈øee the naked, couer him, and de≈øpi≈øe not thy fle≈øh: then ≈øhall thy light breake forth as the morning, and thy health ≈øhall ≈øooner ari≈øe, and thy Iu≈øtice ≈øhall goe before
thy face, and the glorie of our Lord ≈øhall imbrace thee; with ≈øpirituall grace and fauour in this life, and eternall glorie in the other: And ≈øo ≈øayth, Cea≈øe to doe peruer≈øly, learne to I≈øa. 1. 17. doe good (to keepe the Commandements) ≈øeeke iudgement, ≈øuccour the oppre≈ø≈øed, iudge for the fatherle≈ø≈øe, defend the widow, and come and accu≈øe me, ≈øaith our Lord: if your ≈øinnes ≈øhalbe as ≈øcarlet, they ≈øhalbe made white as ≈ønow; and if they be red as vermilion, they ≈øhalbe white as wooll.

Pre≈øently vpon the heartie conuer≈øion of a ≈øinner from his euill wayes, and imbracing the Commandements of God, and louing him with all his heart; our Lord maketh his heart pure, clean, & neat, his coÃÑ≈øcience good, & his faith not fained:
which hee doth by ≈øpirituall Water; according to his Word, ≈øaying: If thou didde≈øt Io. 4. 10. know the gift of God, and who he is, that ≈øaith vnto thee, Giue me to drinke; thou perhaps woulde≈øt haue asked of him, and he would haue giuen thee liuing Water: He that ≈øhall drinke of the Water that I will giue him, ≈øhall not thir≈øt for euer; but the Water that I will giue him, ≈øhall become a Fountaine of Water, ≈øpringing vp to life euerla≈øting. Again, He that beleeueth in me (with a faith that worketh according to charitie) as the Scriptures ≈øay, out of his bellie ≈øhall flowe riuers of liuing Water. Whereupon it is ≈øaid, of ≈øuch as loue God with all their hearts, and keepe his Precepts, that they are whiter Ier. Lam. 4. 7.
then Snow, purer then Milke, ruddier then the old Iuorie, fairer then Saphire. And moreouer, the ≈øoule of a ≈øinner, heartily conuerted to God, is made ≈øo pure, and gracious, by Charitie, that all the Saints and Angels in Heauen doe take plea≈øure and ioy to behold it: as witne≈ø≈øeth our Sauiour, ≈øaying; Luc. 15. 7. There ≈øhall be ioy in Heauen, vpon one ≈øinner that doth Penance. And againe, Luc. 15. 10. I ≈øay to you, that there ≈øhall be ioy, before the Angels of God, vpon one ≈øinner that doth Penance. Neither at this mu≈øt thou maruell; ≈øince a ≈øoule that loueth God, becommeth, by his grace, ≈øo beautifull, as that God Almightie taketh her for his Spou≈øe, and liueth with her in cha≈øte delights,
as in his bed-chamber, hou≈øe, and home; whereof we are to ≈øpeake in the next Chapters.
Beautie corporall, is a proportion of the members, with a certaine ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the mixture of colours.

Beautie ≈øpirituall, is a portion of vertues, with a certaine ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of diuine ≈øplendor; which is of ≈øuch excellencie, that it cannot be expre≈ø≈øed vnto thee, but by changing literall ≈øen≈øe of wordes, into ≈øpirituall: ≈øo ab≈øtract from thy ≈øen≈øes; that thou maye≈øt, in ≈øome part, vnder≈øtand what the Scriptures ≈øay, of the Beautie of a ≈øoule, louing our Lord, and keeping his Commaundements, vnder the≈øe tearmes: How beautifull Cant. 4.
art thou, my Loue, how beautifull art thou: Thy eyes as it were of Doues, be≈øides that which lyeth hid within thee: Thy haires as the flockes of Goates, which haue commed vp from Mount Galaad: Thy teeth as flocks of them that are ≈øhorne, which haue commed vp from wa≈øhing, all with twinnes, and there is not a barren amongst them: Thy lippes as a Scarlet Lace; and thy Speech ≈øweet, as a piece of Pomegranats, ≈øo are al≈øo thy cheekes, be≈øides that which lyeth hid within: Thy necke is as the Tower of Dauid, which is built with Bulwarkes, and thou≈øand Targuets hanging on it, all the Armour of the valiants: Thy low brea≈øts are low Faunes, the twinne of a Roe, which feedeth among the Lillies.
Thou art all faire, O my Loue, and there is not a ≈øpot in thee. So the Scriptures; in expre≈ø≈øing the beautie of a Soule, endued with Charitie, and louing God Almightie with all her heart. Whereupon S. Augu≈øtine ≈øayth, How ≈øhall Aug. in epi≈øt. Ioan. tract. 9. we become faire, or beautifull, but by louing him, who alwayes is beautifull? As much as the loue of him doth encrea≈øe in thee, ≈øo much doth thy beautie encrea≈øe, becau≈øe Charitie is the beautie of the ≈øoule.

And how great happine≈ø≈øe it is, to haue this beautie of ≈øoule, or cleanene≈ø≈øe of heart; our Lord him≈øelfe, in few words, ≈øetteth it downe, ≈øaying, Ble≈ø≈øed are the cleane of heart, for they ≈øhall ≈øee God. For Mat 5. this cau≈øe, God Almightie was
incarnate, and ≈øuffered death, that hee might di≈ø≈øolue ≈øinne, and pre≈øent vs to God immaculate, and pure, that we might ≈øee him, and enioy him; in ≈øeeing and enioying of whom, is con≈øummated all our happine≈ø≈øe. For this (≈øaith S. Iohn) 1. Ioh. 3. 8. appeared the ≈øonne of God, that hee might di≈ø≈øolue the workes of the Deuill, and pre≈øent vs to God pure and immaculate: according to the words of S. Paul, ≈øaying; Whereas you were Col. 1. 21. ≈øometime alienated, and enemies in ≈øen≈øe in euill works: yet now he hath reconciled you, in the body of his fle≈øh, by death, to pre≈øent you holy, and immaculate, and blamele≈ø≈øe, before him. And againe, Eph. 1. 3. Ble≈ø≈øed be God, the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who hath ble≈ø≈øed vs in all ≈øpirituall
ble≈ø≈øings, in heauenly things in Chri≈øt, as he cho≈øe vs in him, before the con≈øtitution of the world, that we ≈øhould be holy, and immaculate, in his ≈øight, in Charitie. And yet adding, ≈øayth; Chri≈øt loued the Church, and Eph. ‚Ä¢ . 15. deliuered him≈øelfe for it, that he might ≈øanctifie it, clean≈øing it by the Lauer of Water in the Word, that hee might pre≈øent to him≈øelfe a glorious Church, not hauing ≈øpot, or wrinckle, or any ≈øuch thing; but that it may be holy, and vn≈øpotted.

So, if it be a Content vnto thee, to haue and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe Beautie corporall, or (cleane Linnen, ≈øoft Apparrell, ≈øtately Pallaces, rich Gardens) which are nothing, but a proportion of earthly thinges,
mixt with varietie of workes, or colours; how farre greater a Content and Happine≈ø≈øe would it be to thee, to haue a pure Heart, and Soule, a good Con≈øcience, and Faith not fained: Which, the loue of God, and keeping his Commaundements, would bring thee vnto; as affirmeth S. Paul, ≈øaying, The end of the Precept is 1. Tim. 1. 5. Charitie, of a pure Heart, and a good Con≈øcience, and a Faith not fained; from the which things, certaine ≈øtraying, are turned into vanitie of words, de≈øirous to be Doctors of the Law, not vnder≈øtanding, neither what things they ≈øpeake, nor of what they affirme: As wee ≈øee, by experience, in the Solifidians of this Age. And this, for the fir≈øt ≈øpirituall
Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, of ≈øuch as keepe the Commaundements.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the ≈øecond ≈øpirituall Content and Happine≈ø≈øe, which ≈øuch enioy, as loue God Almightie with all their hearts, and their Neighbours as them≈øelues; which is, to be beloued of God Almightie.
div.p:
WE ≈øee by experience, that to loue, and not to enioy, or not to be beloued againe, is painefull: ≈øo hauing put all our Content, and Happine≈ø≈øe, in louing his Diuine Maie≈øtie with all our hearts, and all other things for him; if we ≈øhould not be beloued
of his Diuine Maie≈øtie, nor enioy him, we could not be content, or happie.

So ≈øuppo≈øing, that thou firmely beleeue≈øt, that God Almightie is faithfull in all his Promi≈øes, and cannot lye or deceiue, but will performe what≈øoeuer hee hath promi≈øed, if there bee no impediment on thy behalfe; it is nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øhew vnto thee, how hee hath promi≈øed to loue ≈øuch, as loue him with all their hearts, and to make them his Children, Sonnes, and Coheires with our Lord and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and endue them with his Spirit, the holy Gho≈øt, his gifts, and fruits, and maintaine his Oath and Couenant with them, which hee ≈øpoke to Abraham
and his Seed for euer. And fir≈øt, for the Promi≈øes, to loue them that loue him, and keepe his Precepts, he ≈øaith:

He that hath my Commandements, Io. 14. 21. and keepeth them, hee it is that loueth me; and hee that loueth me, ≈øhall be beloued of my Father, and I will loue him. Againe, If any man Io. 14. 23. loue me, he will keepe my Word, and my Father will loue him. Againe, If you keepe my Precepts, Io. 1 ‚Ä¢ . 10. you ≈øhall abide in my loue, as I al≈øo haue kept my Fathers Precepts, and doe abide in his loue. Againe, Io. 16. 27. The Father him≈øelfe loueth you, becau≈øe you haue loued mee. Againe, Hee that keepeth 1. Io. 2. 5. his Word; in him, in verie deed, the Charitie of God is perfited.

Whereby wee ≈øee, that God Almightie cannot but loue tho≈øe, who loue him with all their hearts: and heereupon ari≈øeth all the≈øe amorous tearmes, of cha≈øt loue, betwixt God Almightie, and a ≈øoule that loueth him; ≈øo often ≈øpoken of in the Scriptures, and repeated in the workes, and writings of the Fathers: as Spou≈øe, and E≈øpou≈øe; Ki≈ø≈øe me with the ki≈ø≈øe of his mouth, my loue, my beloued, my beautifull one: How beautifull art thou, my loue, my ≈øi≈øter Spou≈øe, mo≈øt beautifull among≈øt women. And infinite other the like amorous tearmes, and kind ≈øpeeches, expre≈ø≈øing the pa≈ø≈øages of cha≈øt loue, ≈øpirituall plea≈øures, and delights,
exerci≈øed betweene God Almightie, and a Soule, his fauorite.

Whereupon S. Augu≈øtine, in his Booke of Confe≈ø≈øion, calleth God Almightie, His ≈øweet happine≈ø≈øe, the God of his heart, God the light of his heart, the inward bread of the mouth of his ≈øoule, and the vertue, marrying his minde, and the bo≈øome of the thoughts of his minde, &c. In≈øomuch, as all the kindne≈ø≈øes in nature, and exchanges of lawfull naturall affections, v≈øed among≈øt creatures, are but ≈øhadowes, infinitely, a farre off, imitating the kinde pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øpirituall affections, betweene God Almightie, and a Soule, his loue and fauorite; which are ≈øo great, that neither eye 1. Cor. 3. 9.
hath ≈øeene, nor eare hath heard, neither hath it a≈øcended into the heart of (≈øen≈øuall) man, what thinges God hath prepared for them that loue him.

And thou maye≈øt ob≈øerue, that hee doth not wi≈øh them to entreat, or be≈øeech; but, Aske, Mat. 7. 7. and it ≈øhall be giuen you: Verily, verily, I ≈øay to you, If you Io. 15. 7. aske the Father any thing in my Name, he will giue it you. Aske, Io. 16. 24. and you ≈øhall receiue: as if they had authoritie ouer God Almightie. And thou mu≈øt not maruell at it: If God haue Rom. 8. not ≈øpared his owne proper and only begotten Sonne, but hath giuen him vp to death, for gaining vs
vnto him; how can it be, that with him, he hath not giuen vnto vs all other things? Euerie one

Io. 4. 7. that loueth (≈øayth Saint Iohn) is borne of God: not as the Women of this World bring forth their children; who many times, after they be borne, put them to Nur≈øes, and then regard them no more: but with eternall Charitie; which on his part, neuer decayeth, but alwayes remaineth, with ≈øuch feruour, and con≈øtancie, that before hee would part from one ≈øoule, borne of him by Charitie, hee profe≈ø≈øeth, that hee will rather abandon whole Nations. SO great is the happine≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe, who flye ≈øinne, loue God Almightie with all their hearts, and keepe his Commandements; that the Father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt, the Ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie, one God, with all his Diuine Attributes, Excellencies, and Perfections, commeth to dwell, by grace, and fauour, in their

Cor. 6. 14. not the yoake with Infidels: for what participation hath Iu≈øtice with Iniquitie? or what Leuit. 26. 11. ≈øocietie is there betweene light and darkne≈ø≈øe? div.head: OF THE THIRD Fruit of the Holy Gho≈øt, which is Peace.
div.p:

div.head: OF THE FOVRTH fruit of the Holy Gho≈øt, which is Patience.
div.p:
THe fourth fruit is Patience; of which it is ≈øaid: In Patience ≈øhall you po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe Luk. 21, 19. your Soules. Then a man is ≈øaid to enioy a thing, when he receiueth Content in it, and v≈øeth it according to the end it was created; for he that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth a thing to vexe, and afflict, hath it not to enioy, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, but to torment: Whereupon it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe, that angrie and chollericke men doe not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them≈øelues, nor their Soules; ≈øince they

Whereby appeareth the excellencie of this fruit of the Holy Gho≈øt, Patience; that it maketh men Ma≈øters, or iu≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of them≈øelues; in pro≈øperitie, and aduer≈øitie, alwaies to be the ≈øame; and haue, and exerci≈øe at all times, the free v≈øe of rea≈øon, graces, and gifts, which God Almightie hath be≈øtowed vpon them: In Pro≈øperitie, not to be puffed vp with pride, nor wanton with externall Ioyes; and in Aduer≈øitie, not to be deiected, changed, or altered, with Sorrow, or Griefe: As patient Iob ≈øaid;
Our Lord gaue, and our Lord Iob ‚Ä¢ . 2 ‚Ä¢ . hath taken away; as it hath plea≈øed our Lord, ≈øo is it done: the Name of our Lord be ble≈ø≈øed. And ≈øince by Patience we po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe our Soules, what can we e≈øteeme to be of greater worth then Patience? What Mat. 16. 26. exchange will a men giue for his Soule? and giue it to be afflicted with Temporall and Eternall Torments? What doth Mat. 16. 2 ‚Ä¢ . it profit a man, if he gaine the whole World, and ≈øu≈øtaine the damage of his Soule?

By this thou maye≈øt ≈øee how ba≈øely and lightly worldly men doe e≈øteeme of their Soules; ≈øeeing that many times they lo≈øe them through anger, and impatience; rather then they will willingly part from ≈øuperfluous Meate, Drinke, Apparell, e≈øteeme of the World, or ≈øuch like earthly commodities.

O ≈øen≈øuall Man! is not the life (or Soule) more then Mat. 6. Meate, and the Bodie more then Apparell? Be not carefull therefore for the morrow. Be not angrie, or afflicted, for that thou po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe≈øt not ≈øuch worldly things as thou woulde≈øt v≈øe to morrow, For the morrow day ≈øhall be carefull for it ≈øelfe; it will bring new cares with it, Sufficient for the

If thou can≈øt not ea≈øily beare patiently the cares, euils, or malice, which fall vpon thee in one day, why wilt thou put the cares and euils of many dayes together into thy phanta≈øie; and prouoke and ingender in thy ≈øelfe impatiencie, anger, furie, or wrath, to the loo≈øing of thy Soule? Is it, peraduenture, for that thou can≈øt not enioy ≈øome good? If it be not good, what wilt thou doe with it? or why ≈øhoulde≈øt thou be angrie, becau≈øe thou can≈øt not haue that which is naught? THe ≈øixt fruit is Goodne≈ø≈øe, by which they become really and truly good; not by Nature, but by Grace and communication of the Holy Gho≈øt: which produceth in them goodne≈ø≈øe, and an abilitie of doing good workes; according to the words of our Lord, ≈øaying: Euery good tree Mat. 7. 18. yieldeth good fruits, and by their fruits you ≈øhall know them. div.head: OF THE NINTH fruit of the Holy Ghost, which is Faith.
div.p:
THe ninth fruit is Faith, not ≈øuch a Faith as is in Heretikes, and Deuils, who haue their ≈øpirits ≈øo full of malice and iniquitie, that they thinke it impo≈ø≈øible to loue God Almightie with all their Hearts: But a
Faith in their Hearts rooted Eph. 4. 17. and founded in Charitie, that they may be filled vnto all the fulne≈ø≈øe of God, and be now no Eph. 3. 19. more Strangers, and Forrainers, but Citizens of the Saints, and the Domesticals of God; treating with him in their Soules, by Faith, that worketh Gal. 5, 6. by Charitie.

A Faith planted in a good Luk, 8, 15, and very good Heart, which hearing the Word, doth retaine it, and yield fruit in Patience, Mat, 13, 29, ≈øome an hundreth fold, and other three≈øcore, and another, thirtie.
A Faith, Light of the World, Mat, 5, 15, ≈øhining before men: that they may ≈øee your good workes, and glorifie your Father which is in Heauen.

A Faith dilated all ouer the
World; Teach ye all Nations: Mat. 28 19. And they going forth Mar. 16. 20. preached euery where. Into Rom. 16. 18. al the Earth hath the ≈øound of them gone forth; and vnto the end of the whole World, the words of them. In the Col. 1. 6. whole World it is, and fructifieth and groweth.

The Faith of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Gal. 3. 22. giuen to them that beleeue. The Iu≈øtice of God by Faith Rom. 3. 22. 31 of Ie≈øus Christ, whereby we doe not destroy the Law, but e≈øtabli≈øh the Law: according to the words of our Sauiour, ≈øaying; Doe not thinke that Mat. 5. 18. I came to breake the Law or the Prophets; I came not to breake, but to fulfill.

A Faith, which who≈øoeuer beleeueth, and doth according to that which he beleeueth, As the Scriptures ≈øay, out of his belly ≈øhall flow Ioh. 7. 38. Riuers of liuing water. And I≈øa. 12. 3. he ≈øhall draw waters in ioy, out
of the Fountaines of our Sauiour, and be inebriated with P≈øa. 35. 9. the plentie of the hou≈øe of God; and with the torrent of his plea≈øure, be made drunke.

div.head: OF THE TENTH fruit of the Holy Gho≈øt, which is Mode≈øtie.
div.p:

And againe to Timothie: The Seruant of our Lord mu≈øt 2. Tim. 2 24. not wrangle, but be milde towards all men; apt to teach; patient; with modestie admoni≈øhing them that re≈øist the Truth (Heretikes and Schi≈ømatikes) lea≈øt ≈øometime God giue them Repentance to know

Againe, Let your mode≈øtie Phil. 4. 5. be knowne to all men, our Lord is nigh. Whereupon S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith: He made Conf. li. 4. ca. 12. the≈øe things, and is not farre off from them: for he did not make them, and then goe his waies; but of him, and in Act. 17. 28. him, they are; for in him we liue, and moue, and be.

But the eies of the Eph. 4. 15. Wi≈øe are in his Head, looking vpon our Lord, who is our Head: and there ≈øo content, that he little careth or de≈øireth to ≈øee any thing el≈øe, more then nece≈ø≈øitie requireth.

So the Prophet Dauid ≈øaith: To thee haue I lifted vp mine P≈ø. 122. eyes, which dwelleth in the Heauens: Behold, as the eyes of Seruants are to the hand of their Ma≈øter; as the eyes of the Hand-maid, on the
hands of her Mi≈øtres; ≈øo our eies, to our Lord God.

Againe, I fore≈øaw our Lord in my ≈øight alwaies, becau≈øe P≈ø. 15. 8. he is at my right hand, that I be not moued; for this thing my heart hath beene glad, and my tongue hath reioiced: moreouer, al≈øo my fle≈øh ≈øhall rest in hope.

div.head: OF THE ELEVENTH fruit of the Holy Gho≈øt, which is Continencie.
div.p:
Continencie in generall, con≈øi≈øting in the acts of Ab≈øtinence, and Mortification, doth crucifie or make dead the inordinate de≈øires of the Fle≈øh: That the iustification Rom. 8. of the Law might be fulfilled in vs, who walke not according to the Fle≈øh, but according to the Spirit. For they that are according to the fle≈øh, are affected to the things that are of the fle≈øh (as we ≈øee by too much experience in carnall Heretikes, who profe≈ø≈øe publikely in Print, That they cannot liue cha≈øte) But they that are according to
the Spirit, are affected to the things that are of the Spirit, that is to ≈øay, to Continencie, Cha≈øtitie, Charitie, &c. For Rom. 8. the Wi≈ødome of the Fle≈øh, is death; but the Wi≈øedome of the Spirit, life and peace.

Such as liue according to the concupi≈øcences and de≈øires of the Fle≈øh, are dead to Grace in this life, and to Glory in the other; But ≈øuch as liue according to the wi≈øedome of the Spirit, in Continencie and Cha≈øtitie, by mortifying their inordinate appetites, ≈øhall liue with the life of Grace in this life, & of Glory in the other, and in Temporall peace of minde in this life, and Eternall in the other:
Becau≈øe the Wi≈øedome of the Rom. 8. 13. Fle≈øh, is an enemie to God; for to the Law of God it is not ≈øubiect, neither can it be: for if you liue according to the Fle≈øh, you ≈øhall die; but if by the Spirit you mortifie the deedes of the Fle≈øh, you ≈øhall liue. For who≈øoeuer are led by the Spirit of God (and mortifie the deeds of the Fle≈øh) they are the ≈øonnes of God. But if any man haue not the Spirit of Chri≈øt (the Spirit of Continencie, and Mortification) the ≈øame is not his, but the Deuils. Whereupon Saint Paul yet further ≈øaith: I ≈øay, walke Gal. 5. 16. in the Spirit (that is, in doing acts of Mortification, and Continencie) and the

If the inordinate lu≈øt and de≈øires of the Fle≈øh preuaile ≈øo farre with thee, as that they bring thy Will, Rea≈øon, and Soule, to con≈øent to their de≈øires: then, the inordinate lu≈øt, and concupi≈øences of the Fle≈øh, are Lords and Ma≈øters; and thy Will, Rea≈øon, and Soule, become ≈ølaues to their owne va≈ø≈øals; and thou becomme≈øt a bea≈øt, and a bea≈øtly man, to runne after thy fle≈øhly Lu≈øts, and Concupi≈øences; like the wilde A≈ø≈øes and

If thy Soule, or vpper part, make continent, and mortifie thy Lu≈øts, and Carnall de≈øires, and inordinate appetites of thy fle≈øh; then thy Soule, or vpper part, is Lord and Ma≈øter; and thou liue≈øt like a man, or rea≈øonable creature, and not like a bea≈øt: and comme≈øt, by per≈øeuerance in Continencie and Mortification, to enioy the≈øe delicate Fruits of the Holy Ghost, which heere we treate of. And for this cau≈øe, the Life of Man is Iob. 7. called a Warfare. For the Fle≈øh Gal. ‚Ä¢ . ‚Ä¢ 7. lu≈øteth again≈øt the Spirit, and the Spirit against the Fle≈øh:

Who ≈øhall deliuer me (≈øaith Rom. 7. S. Paul) from the bodie of this death? the Grace of God, by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord. Again, The Grace of God our Sauiour 1. Ti ‚Ä¢

div.p:
